10025.description: BECOME A SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING and MATH (STEM) VOLUNTEER! Help middle school and high school students develop a passion for math and science by becoming a dedicated instructor, teaching assistant, or afterschool tutor. Whether you're great, good or fair at Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM), you can help make an impact on inner-city youth. Here's how: The Parris Foundation S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program has returned for the Spring 2017 session . The program began after a successful summer pilot in 2012, and our subsequent programs have grown to continue to serve middle school students and high school students . With the growing impact on the community, we need your support to continue to bring STEM to our middle school and high school youth throughout New York City . As we expand to more locations to serve more youth, there is a growing need for volunteers! Our ideal volunteer is enthusiastic about working with youth, can commit to multiple Saturdays, and possesses, at minimum, basic science and math skills. No previous education experience is required. Your passion for science and math coupled with a desire to help New York City youth realize their true potential is all that is required.
10025.title: Spring & Summer 2017 - S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program

10025.description: Would you like to make a difference with your dog? Disadvantaged children in New York City need help. Now you and your dog can help them. Become a volunteer team for A Fair Shake for Youth. A Fair Shake for Youth, Inc. is a non-profit that uses therapy dogs and AKC Canine Good Citizens to help middle-school aged youth in underserved communities build greater empathy and self-esteem, and reduce bullying. Dedicated volunteers and their dogs are at the heart of our program, power and success. Here's how it works: Three volunteer/dog teams each commit to a ten-week program Transportation is provided Teams work with the same group of 12 kids, becoming a consistent part of their school life Kids form a relationship with the volunteers and share the experience of making the dogs successful Volunteers experience a profound connection to the students - their struggles and success. Volunteers must be registered therapy dogs or AKC Canine Good Citizens.If your dog is not already one of these, training is available. We are looking for dogs that love people (especially children), are good with new situations, are resilient and well-mannered. For more information, please visit our website at www.afairshakeforyouth.org . If you and your dog would like to volunteer with us, please email volunteer@afairshakeforyouth.org
10025.title: Volunteer Dog Teams
10025.org: A Fair Shake for Youth, Inc.

10025.description: Walking Tour Guide Would you love to meet people from around the world? Do you love to show people around New York City? Everyday, we offer walking tours to see and experience New York City. This is the perfect opportunity to meet people from around the world. Daily Walking Tours meet at our beautiful Victorian mansion on the Upper West Side. From meeting location, we offer tours to Central Park, Brooklyn Bridge and all types of locations in the five boroughs of New York City.. Note: All volunteers must be punctual and able to commit to regular attendance over a 12-week term. Volunteers will: Give weekly or multi-weekly tours Foreign language ability is a plus but not a requirement Leaders can request tours for specific locations in the five boroughs Serve as representatives of New York to a global audience Help develop your public speaking and communication skills Receive volunteer hours that can be applied towards free hostel stays anywhere in our network of over 50 hostels in the USA Be eligible for volunteer trainings, appreciation events and more If you’re interested, please contact activities.newyork@hiusa.org for an application and more information or visit http://hinewyork.org/volunteer to apply. We’re looking for people who love to travel! HI New York is the largest nonprofit organization dedicated to youth travel in New York, and the largest hostel in North America.
10025.title: Walking Tour Guide

10025.description: Volunteering your time to change the lives of adults with developmental disabilities. Sprout is a non-profit organization based in New York City focused on providing innovative programs for adults with developmental disabilities.With our network of resources and dedicated volunteers, which we call leaders, Sprout opens up fascinating new worlds to people with disabilities. Sprout's Overnight Vacations Program is looking for individuals who have the energy, motivation and desire to work with adults with developmental disabilities. What do Sprout leaders do? Sprout leaders' primary goal is to give adults with developmental disabilities the opportunity to experience and enjoy recreational, educational and leisure activities through overnight vacations. Leaders are responsible for the overall safety and enjoyment of their group, 24 hours a day, while on a Sprout trip. Duties include safety monitoring, personal hygiene assistance, providing physical and emotional support, activity planning, budgeting, logistics, and enhancing fun. The work is hard yet immensely rewarding as you develop leadership skills and gain insight into your own abilities. What type of training is provided? Leaders must complete a pre-service training, which provides the necessary procedures and tools to run a successful and enjoyable vacation. Leaders who are drivers receive extra training on how to safely drive our 15-passenger vans. In addition, all leaders receive a copy of Sprout's Leadership Handbook to help with policies and guidelines. What is the time commitment? Sprout vacations last 3 - 7 days depending on the time of year and destination of the trip. When a leader is selected for an overnight vacation, Sprout asks that the leader dedicate themselves to stay with their group throughout the entire duration of the vacation. Some leaders only choose to lead one trip a year while others spend several months with us leading up to 8 trips or more. Sprout strives to make our program flexible for our leaders based on the amount of time leaders can give. Do leaders have any free or personal time while on a trip? Sprout trips are working vacations for the leaders who choose to participate. Because Sprout leaders are responsible for their group 24 hours a day, there is no free or personal time allotted. In order to give our participants the opportunity to experience and enjoy a vacation, Sprout leaders must be available at all times to provide the support any one participant may need. What type of trips can Sprout leaders expect to join? A majority of Sprout trips take place within a day's drive of New York City. Destinations include Atlantic City, Amish Country, Boston, Lake George, Cleveland, Maine and Virginia Beach. Exotic trips like cruises, Hawaii, and Europe are presented to leaders who have demonstrated high levels of commitment, service hours and have gained positive feedback from participants and Sprout office staff. Are there any special skills or requirements? No special background or education is required to become a Sprout leader. We encourage people from all cultures and professions, and of all ethnic and educational backgrounds. Once accepted into the program, you will receive the necessary tools to sign up for outings and how to assist our participants. Requirements include: -21+ years old -Provide references -Participate in training session -Willingness to complete necessary background checks -Evaluate participants' behavior -Fluent English -Willing to drive a 15 passenger van -Love to travel & have fun! How do I apply? TO APPLY: http://gosprout.org/vacation-programs/volunteer/volunteer-application/
10025.title: Vacation Trip Leader

10025.description: Make a difference by becoming a Sprout Day Trip Leader! Are you passionate about working with people who have developmental disabilities? Are you looking for a fun, flexible opportunity where you can actually see the difference that you're making? If so, Sprout may be exactly what you're looking for! Sprout's NYC Program provides evening and weekend recreational activities for highly-social adults with mild-to-moderate developmental disabilities. These activities are all over the five boroughs of New York City and include sporting events, museums, art classes, festivals, dinners and more! Sprout Leaders provide supervision to our groups for 2-6 hour long excursions while encouraging positive socialization and having fun with them. Leaders also assist with some logistical elements of activities such as handling a small budget or directing a participant to the nearest subway station. Each month, Leaders are sent a calendar of events and can choose the activities they would like to lead. We only ask that Leaders follow through with the commitment they make to assist with those activities. NO special background or education is required to become a Sprout leader. We encourage people from all cultures and professions, and of all ethnic and educational backgrounds. Once accepted into the program, you will receive a training session which will provide the necessary tools to sign up for and lead future activities. *We encourage applicants with diverse experience-levels and backgrounds *Must be 21 years or older *Fluency in English required TO APPLY: h ttp: gosprout.org/vacation-programs/volunteer/ OR EMAIL: l eadership@gosprout.org

11222.description: Northside Charter High School is looking for a Volunteer Board of Trustees Member. This position is reporting to the Chairperson, Board of Trustees (\"Board\"). General Responsibilities: Each trustee is responsible for actively participating in the work of the Northside Charter High School (\"NCHS\" or the \"School\") Board of Trustees (\"Board\") and the life of the school. Each trustee is expected to affirm and strive to fulfill the performance expectations outlined below. These expectations are to be clearly articulated prior to nominating any candidate as a board member. The NCHS Board will nominate the candidate only after s/he has agreed to fulfill these expectations. In addition to the responsibilities below, individual trustees are expected to help each other fulfill the tasks outlined in the collective Job Description of the Board of Trustees. Qualifications: Endorsement and support for the charter and mission of NCHS. An understanding of NCHS as a nonprofit, public charter high school. An understanding that every member of the Board of Trustees serves the entire school and that their service on the Board does not constitute representation on any one constituency of the School. Ability to provide resources and expertise or experience in support of the School. Demonstrate the highest ethical standards and integrity in personal and public conduct. Specific Responsibilities: General Support the School’s mission, purposes, goals, policies, programs, services, strengths and needs. Perform duties of Board membership responsibly. Suggest possible nominees to the Board who are clearly people of achievement and distinction and who can contribute significantly to the work of the Board and the School’s progress. Avoid prejudiced judgments on the basis of information received from individuals and urge those with grievances to follow established policies and procedures. Follow trends in the School’s field of interest Bring goodwill, candor and thoughtfulness to the Board’s deliberations Meetings Prepare for and participate in Board and Committee meetings, including appropriate organizational activities. Ask timely and substantive questions at Board and Committee meetings consistent with your conscience and convictions while supporting the majority decision on issues resolved by the Board Maintain confidentiality of the Board’s executive sessions, and speak for the Board only when authorized to do so. Potential Conflicts Serve the School as a whole rather than any special interest group or constituency, putting the interest of the School first. Avoid even the appearance of a conflict of interest that might embarrass the Board or the School, and disclose any possible conflicts in a timely fashion. Protect the integrity of the Board and School by resigning from the Board in order to accept- or even be considered for- a position with the School, understanding that such action would eliminate the possibility of future service on the Board. Fiduciary Responsibilities Exercise prudence with the Board in the control and oversight of funds and assets. Faithfully read and understand the School’s financial statements and otherwise help the Board fulfill its fiduciary duties. Fundraising Assist the Board and staff by implementing fundraising strategies through cooperation and personal influence with others (corporations, foundations, and individuals). APPLICATION PROCEDURES To apply, please send resume and letter of qualifications and interest to karaffakaley@gmail.com.

Treatment includes assessment and short and long term psychotherapy using multiple and flexible treatment modalities including individual, couple family and group treatment as well as evidence based psychotherapies. 10020.description: You can make a BIG difference in the life of a child. Become a BIG Brother/BIG Sister with The Jewish Board. Help a child become happier, more fulfilled, and better able to face the challenges of childhood or adolescence. The Big Brother Big Sister Program (BBBS) matches volunteers with children, ages 7-16 years old, who could benefit from an additional positive role model in their lives, positively impacting the well-being of the child. These children come from single parent families, special family circumstances, and/or are receiving services from The Jewish Board. Volunteers must be 21 years or older, available to spend between once a week and once a month with the child and make a minimum of a year commitment. We create and support matches that are positive, safe, and well suited to your and the child’s needs. Our Bigs come from all different backgrounds, and so do our Littles. Our professional staff carefully screens Bigs and Littles to make the best match possible based on common interests, personalities and location. Your commitment has a powerful impact on the life of a child.

10021.description: Make a Connection Be a Spanish Speaking Telephone Reassurance Volunteer Background: Established in 1893, Visiting Nurse Service of New York is the nation’s largest not-for-profit home based healthcare company. As a payer (Medicare Advantage, Medicaid Long Term Care) and a provider (homecare, hospice, long term care), VNSNY services more than 140,000 individuals a year in the metro New York City marketplace. Each day, over 10,000 VNSNY nurses, rehabilitation therapists, social workers, and allied professionals and paraprofessionals deliver compassionate care, unparalleled medical expertise, and 24/7 solutions. VNSNY’s charitable care and community benefit initiatives ensure that all patients receive the full range of care they need, regardless of the limits of their health care coverage. In 2016, we provided more than $16.7 million through these programs, made possible, in part, by the generous support of foundations, corporations, and individual donors. Position Description: The volunteer will make weekly phone calls to frail elderly and disabled VNSNY patients in New York City who have been identified by nurses and/or social workers as needing telephone companionship. Brief notes must be recorded on office patient log. Qualifications: Genuine desire to interact with isolated patients; good listening skills; pleasant telephone manner and voice; ability to take notes and fill out form. Attendance at one training session and familiarization with training manual required. Bilingual callers in Spanish are needed. Benefits: Satisfaction derived from interacting with patients; assisting in important patient contact to help VNSNY improve service delivered to patients; chance to work with committed professionals and volunteers; Annual Volunteer Recognition Luncheon Start Date: Flexible with minimum commitment of six months. Hours: 1.5 - 2+ hours per week to complete calls to patients from our East 70th Street headquarters. Hours are flexible 9:00 - 5:00 weekdays. Location: 107 East 70 th St., between Lexington & Park Avenues New York, NY 10021 To Apply: Interested candidates should forward cover letter and resume by e-mail to: Volguest@vnsny.org
10021.title: Brighten A Seniors Day!
10021.org: Visiting Nurse Service of New York

10021.title: New York, NY: Autism Volunteer (East 72nd Street)

10021.description: We are seeking early evening and overnight hosts for our homeless shelter. We are particularly interested in overnight hosts. Our shelter runs every week of the year, from Sunday-Thursday. The early evening host (6:30pm-8:30pm): Welcomes and checks-in the guests. Prepares the breakfast tray. Offers a light snack for those who missed dinner at the Drop-in Center. Makes sure that everyone has enough linens, blankets, and toiletries to be comfortable and cleans up the table and kitchen. The overnight host (8:30pm-7:00am): Organizes food clean-up with help from the guests. Makes sure breakfast is ready to go. Ensures the smooth operation of the shelter overnight, from 10:00pm lights-out to wake up, breakfast and departure in the morning. Leaves the kitchen and guest area clean and neat. Early and Overnight Hosts can volunteer by themselves or with a friend/partner/family member/etc. Our volunteers are committed to serving our shelter guests. Most hosts serve at least twice/month. Prospective hosts must attend an Open House orientation or contact us to arrange for an individual orientation. Open House Orientations are held on a monthly basis at 1:00 p.m., meeting at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. We rely on our volunteer hosts to keep the shelter open, so we need dependable volunteers to show up for and complete every shift they agree to fill. Volunteers must be 18 or older. Volunteers must also be able to lift 20 lbs for snack set-up.
10021.title: Volunteers needed at Upper East Side Homeless Shelter

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premiere human services providers, is a 123-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 20,000 people in need each year, ages 3 to 103 on Manhattan's East Side. We are seeking volunteers to staff the Reception/Information desk of our vibrant, busy Senior Center on Tuesdays or Wednesdays, 9:00-12:00 or two Saturdays per month 9:00-12:00. Volunteers will be responsible for checking in senior center members for meals and activities, answering in-person and phone inquiries, signing members up for trips and other light clerical tasks.
10021.title: Senior Center Receptionist

Our shelter runs every week of the year, from Sunday-Thursday. The early evening host (6:30pm-8:30pm): Welcomes and checks-in the guests. Prepares the breakfast tray. Offers a light snack for those who missed dinner at the Drop-in Center. Makes sure that everyone has enough linens, blankets, and toiletries to be comfortable and cleans up the table and kitchen. The overnight host (8:30pm-7:00am): Organizes food clean-up with help from the guests. Makes sure breakfast is ready to go. Ensures the smooth operation of the shelter overnight, from 10:00pm lights-out to wake up, breakfast and departure in the morning. Leaves the kitchen and guest area clean and neat. Early and Overnight Hosts can volunteer by themselves or with a friend/partner/family member/etc. Our volunteers are committed to serving our shelter guests. Most hosts serve at least twice/month. Prospective hosts must attend an Open House orientation or contact us to arrange for an individual orientation. Open House Orientations are held on a monthly basis at 1:00 p.m., meeting at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. We rely on our volunteer hosts to keep the shelter open, so we need dependable volunteers to show up for and complete every shift they agree to fill. Volunteers must be 18 or older. Volunteers must also be able to lift 20 lbs for snack set-up.
10021.title: Homeless Shelter Hosts

10021.description: Purpose Assist with registering seniors for lunch, class and events. Responsibilities * Greet senior center members * Assist with sign in and selling tickets for lunch * Assist with registering seniors for trips * Additional clerical assistance as needed Skills * Ability to work independently and as part of a team * Good organizational skills and the ability to prioritize and manage multiple tasks * Strong communication skills * Patience Other * Flexible scheduling is available with a minimum commitment of one day a week during business hours * Ongoing opportunity * Must be available 10 AM - 2 PM on a weekday * Maintain professional behavior at all times and adhere to JASA’s volunteer policies About JASA Founded in 1968, JASA's mission is to sustain and enrich the lives of the aging in the New York metropolitan area so that they can remain in the community with dignity and autonomy. JASA is one of New York's largest and most trusted agencies serving older adults in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, and Long Island.
10021.title: Registrar - JASA Club 76

11219.description: The role of a volunteer at Maimonides Infants and Children’s Hospital is to provide supplemental service to the staff and to fill the multiple needs of the child and family while in the hospital. Volunteers at Maimonides Infants & Children’s Hospital are assigned by the Department of Volunteer Services and while on duty are directly responsible to the Child Life Supervisor/Designee. Child Life volunteers are prepared to function independently providing play, recreational, and supportive activities to children and their families on the Pediatric unit they are trained to. These activities assist in making patients feel safe and comfortable. Volunteers serve in the playroom as well as at the bedside when requested. Specific Volunteer Opportunities Available: Skilled Group Leader - If you have a special skill you would like to share with our families like music, singing, arts & crafts, knitting, scrapbooking, storytelling, puppetry, etc. ( 2 hours a week for at Least 6 months) Volunteer in Play Room or Teen Room- Help provide materials at bedside and play or do arts and crafts with children and teens in the play areas.( 4 hours a week for at least 6 months)
11219.title: Playroom Volunteer

11219.description: At Boro Park Counseling Center, we provide individual, couples, family, and group counseling in a comfortable, confidential environment by licensed Frum mental health professionals. Psychiatric evaluations and medication management are available for clients in treatment. We serve people of all ages. As a Yoga Instructor at our center, you will teach beginner's yoga to our clients.
11219.title: Yoga Instructor - Brooklyn (Boro Park)
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

11219.description: At Boro Park Counseling Center, we provide individual, couples, family, and group counseling in a comfortable, confidential environment by licensed Frum mental health professionals. Psychiatric evaluations and medication management are available for clients in treatment. We serve people of all ages. We are looking for volunteers with licensed pet therapy animals to visit our center to spend some quality time with our clients. Spending time with animals is an incredibly therapeutic activity for our clients, and rain or shine, it is always a great way to make them smile.
11219.title: Pet Therapist - Brooklyn (Boro Park)
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

11219.description: At Boro Park Counseling Center, we provide individual, couples, family, and group counseling in a comfortable, confidential environment by licensed Frum mental health professionals. Psychiatric evaluations and medication management are available for clients in treatment. We serve people of all ages. As the ESL Tutor, you will be teaching Yiddish speaking adult clients basic English. You will be teaching through conversation and activities like flashcards, games and songs.
11219.title: ESL Tutor - Brooklyn (Boro Park)
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

11219.description: MJHS Hospice provides a specialized program of care and services for end-of-life patients. MJHS Hospice provides care for pediatric and adult patients in homes, nursing homes, assisted living communities, inpatient facilities and hospitals. MJHS Hospice Volunteer opportunities include: Providing support and companionship to patients and their families Participating in leisure activities such as reading, listening to music, playing games with patients Supporting or organizing group activities for patients Listening compassionately to patients and their families Providing office or clerical support for our hospice team Complementary therapies Requirements for all categories of volunteers: 18 years or older 15 hours of training (4 hours training for clerical/office volunteers) Background Check (no charge to applicant) Medical Clearance (no charge to applicant) 3-4 hours per week 1 year commitment Required skills for patient visits: discretion, patience, compassion and dedication Preferred clerical and office support skills include: receptionist skills, computer skills, organizational skills and filing For more information on how to become a MJHS Hospice Volunteer please call: Brooklyn: Denise Jones, Coordinator of Volunteer Services; 347-633-3421 or dejones@mjhs.org
11219.title: Be Part of Someone's Legacy--Become a Hospice Volunteer in Brooklyn!

11219.description: We need musicians, Singers, Vocalist and Instrumentalist of all kinds and Languages to come help lift up the spirit of the helpless members of our community.
11219.title: Help Uplift The Helpless Through Music

11219.description: Sometimes a friendly face is all it takes to make someone's day, and Mishkon's Companion Program brings new friendly faces to the individuals in our program! The Companion Program matches individuals in Brooklyn with a companion; volunteers who will make a short visit, just to say hi. As a companion you can play a game, listen to some music simply have a short conversation with your new Mishkon friend. For individuals who have a developmental disability, your friendship can decrease a sense of isolation and provide a welcome change from day-to-day activities. We will match you with one of our program's individuals based on your mutual interests and availability. Time commitment and hours are flexible.
11219.title: Client Companion - Brooklyn
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

11219.description: The Mishkon Division services the needs of people with developmental disabilities via their residences, Medicaid Waiver program, respite program, and summer sleepaway camp. As a Weekly Host, you will lead a Shabbat party in a group home or apartment of our Mishkon clients choosing. Games, snacks, and activities will be included. To register for our volunteer website, please visit www.jewishboard.org/volunteer.
11219.title: Weekly Shabbat Party Host- Brooklyn
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

11219.description: The Mishkon Division services the needs of people with developmental disabilities via their residences, Medicaid Waiver program, respite program, and summer sleepaway camp. As a Team Activity Leader at Mishkon you will be responsible for leading activities with developmentally disabled male and/or female adolescents and adults in their residences. Activities may include, but are not limited to, Arts & Crafts, Cooking/baking, Going out into the community, Musical activities, Exercise/Dance activities, and Reading/Games. As a Team Activity Leader you can also bring your own ideas and skills to the table. You must be caring and responsible, and willing to learn about the developmentally disabled population.
11219.title: Activity Specialist - Brooklyn
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

11219.description: The Mishkon Division services the needs of people with developmental disabilities via their residences, Medicaid Waiver program, respite program, and summer sleepaway camp. As a Personal Shopper for our Mishkon residents you will work together with staff and residence managers to collect clothing sizes of special needs men and women. The volunteer will shop with or without the individual, in program-approved locations and stay within a pre-established budget. The volunteer will be responsible for returning or exchanging items that don't fit. Volunteer must be willing to learn about the developmentally disabled population, have good communication skills, and work well with others.
11219.title: Personal Shopper- Brooklyn
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

11219.description: The Mishkon Division services the needs of people with developmental disabilities via their residences, Medicaid Waiver program, respite program, and summer sleepaway camp. As a Fundraiser you will take initiative to fundraise, collect donations, or run a toy drive to collect approved items for children and adults with special needs. Creativity and \"out of the box thinking\" is welcome. Volunteer will hand out donated items to individuals. Volunteer must be open to learning about the developmentally disabled population, be able to take initiative, have excellent interpersonal and communication skills, and work well with others. Hours will vary.
11219.title: Fundraiser- Brooklyn
11219.org: Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services

08835.description: Welcome to the ASD Climber Foundation! ASD stands for Autism Spectrum Disorders. We are working with a family in your area with a child on the autism spectrum. The family wants to train volunteers to help them run a home based social skills program called the Son-Rise Program. No experience necessary. Free training provided. Time commitment is 2-4 hours a week for 6 months or more. PLEASE READ: After completing the \"I want to help\" page, you will immediately receive an auto reply email with our Volunteer Profile. Please fill this out, and we will forward it directly to the family in your area that requires help. ***please add asdclimberfoundation@me.com to your safe list and check your junk mail if you do not see an immediate response in your inbox*** Thank you for your time!
08835.title: Manville, NJ: Autism Volunteer

08837.description: Canine Companions for Independence has an opening for an Event Chair and DogFest committee to lead the planning of the 2017 DogFest New Jersey Walk N Roll. Event Chair must be available to meet once a month for committee meetings and have ability to assist committee members in soliciting sponsors, recruiting teams and participants and publicizing the event. Position description is below but subject to change. Event Chair candidates will need to meet with Canine Companions staff before being accepted for the position. DogFest Chairperson Work with Staff Partner to identify and recruit Committee Chairs. With the Committee Chairs, recruit volunteers to fill committee positions. Manage the committee through the planning process. Communicate with Staff Partner to ensure they are in the loop through the entire process. Serve as spokesperson for DogFest in the community Organization and communication skills to coordinate and lead committee meetings Have a well-developed network of potential sponsors, vendors and committee members Creativity to come up with ideas for fund-raising Ability to participate in meetings during work days and evenings both by phone and face to face in Irving Follow up skills needed to keep various committee info updated and on track Passion for the cause because it will come out in the message presented Ability and willingness to speak in public meetings and at Canine Companions events to promote DogFest and drive committee membership and event participation Ability to assist committee in soliciting sponsorships, recruiting teams and participants and publicizing event Previous event planning and fundraising experience helpful
08837.title: Dogfest Walk 'n Roll Chairperson or commitee member
08837.org: CANINE COMPANIONS FOR INDEPENDENCE - NORTHEAST REGION (Maine to Virginia)

08837.description: We are a non-profit looking for positive-minded adult volunteers of all ages to help with various projects for our growing organization. The hours are flexible - come when you can, stay as long as you like - just let us know. We need talents of all types from social media friendly to data entry savvy volunteers and everything in between. Join us in our exciting new Education Center in Raritan Center Business Park in Edison and meet our wonderful staff who are dedicated to our mission of empowering young people to own their economic success. Learn more about us at www.janj.org
08837.title: Social media savvy or more traditional ?  We need you!

08837.description: If you have an hour or more per week to give, Grace Healthcare Services welcomes your gifts of time and compassion. Whether you choose to work directly with patients and families or to volunteer in one of many other ways, you can make a profound difference in someone's life, including your own. Volunteers are an integral part of the hospice team. We are currently in need of Office volunteers! Our Administrative/Office Volunteers provide help to the staff in our Edison office by filing, organizing, creating folders, organizing newsletters, collating manuals and participating in special projects. You will also get to work very closely with our compassionate staff, creating bonds while gaining valubale hospice insight. For more information about our available volunteer opportunities, call our Volunteer Department or visit our website at Gracehcs.com! We look forward to hearing from you!
08837.title: Office Volunteers Needed!

08837.description: Position Summary: The Disability Allies (DA) is dedicated to providing social opportunities to connect young adults and children with and without disabilities. The Walkathon Director is a part time volunteer position that involves a commitment of a few hours a week. You must be willing to join us at our monthly committee meetings at the Milltown Public Library at 10am on the Second Saturday of the Month. The Walkathon Director will oversee and be the point of contact for our Walkathon. Responsibilities: The Walkathon Director will oversee and be the point of contact for our Walkathon. He or she will have the following responsibilities: Effectively run and be the point of contact for our Walkathon Set up all the activities at our Walkathon Oversee the registration of our teams Coordinate all logistics including EMS, Police and the location Be in direct communication with senior leadership of our organization Obtain sponsorships from various business and organizations Answer and respond to questions that people have about our walkathon Essential functions/working conditions: Must be able to meet deadlines and adjust to changing priorities Must be proficient in Microsoft Office Able to effectively communicate both verbally and in writing Ability to connect with others and develop relationships Committed to the mission of serving young adults with disabilities Ability to perform several tasks concurrently Strong time management and organizational skills Ability to maintain detailed records and confidential information About the Disability Allies: The purpose of the Disability Allies is to plan team building activities that connect young adults and children with and without disabilities. At our events we pair each individual up with a mentor. The job of the mentor is to help the participants with their social skills and insure that everyone interacts with each other. Our events are open to any young adult that has a disability, knows someone with a disability or is supportive of people with disabilities. Please visit www.disabilityallies.com to learn more. Disability Allies Anti-Discrimination statement: Disability Allies shall not discriminate on the basis of race, color, religion (creed), gender, age, national origin (ancestry), disability, marital status, sexual orientation, political affiliation, gender identification or expression, or military status in any of its activities of operations. These activities include, but are not limited to, hiring and firing of staff, selection of volunteers, and selection of vendors and provision of services.
08837.title: Walkathon Director

These activities include, but are not limited to, hiring and firing of staff, selection of volunteers, and selection of vendors and provision of services.
08837.title: Walkathon Coordinator

08837.description: Catholic Charities Connections Program is actively recruiting volunteers to work as mentors with children ages 5-17. Mentors offer support, guidance, and education as a youth goes through a difficult time, faces new challenges or opportunities, or takes on an important task. A mentor is a person who is willing to share their life-long expertise to provide support to the youth. Mentors can play an important role as the youth develops mentally and emotionally to help a youth understand their goals and personal needs. Mentors must be a minimum of 18 years of age. Prospective mentors will undergo an intensive screening process consisting of: application and informal autobiography, personal interview, reference checks, criminal background check, driving record check and program orientation. The program serves youth in Middlesex County. Mentoring is the process of sharing personal knowledge and skills with a young person.
08837.title: Adult Mentor

08837.description: Assist survivors of sexual violence through our 24-hour hotline, accompaniment to forensic examinations, and support through the legal process at local police stations and court. No experience is necessary for this opportunity however a 50 Hour Confidential Sexual Violence Advocate Training is required and provided by our center. Must be 18 or older and have reliable transportation. Daytime, evening, weekends and holiday availability needed.Bilingual indviduals are encouraged to apply.
08837.title: Confidential Sexual Violence Advocate

08831.description: Parker is a non-profit senior service organization, serving elders throughout the central Jersey area for over 100 years. Our campus Parker at Monroe, is a Nursing Care Residence for elders in Monroe Township with physical and cognitive needs. We are in search of pet volunteers to visit our loving residents at Parker at Monroe. Requirements: Animals:Dog/Cat Must be friendly Must have up to date vaccination records Must fill out volunteer application
08831.title: Pet Volunteers Needed at Monroe Township Nursing Home!

08831.description: Marketplace in Jamesburg is a great opportunity for volunteers to impact the lives of families in the community. The Deacon’s Food Cupboard provides food allotments that include perishable and non-perishable items, to over 80 families every month. Volunteers are needed to help distribute food to families in need. Help fight hunger today! NOTE: To participate in this project you must be a Jersey Cares volunteer. To sign up as a Jersey Cares volunteer: 1. Visit www.jerseycares.org 2. Click on \"Log-In\" 3. Click on \"Not a Member? Register\" 4. Fill out all necessary information. 5. Register for a project!
08831.title: Marketplace in Jamesburg

08831.description: Do you have wisdom to share? Are you 60 or better and enjoy offering guidance to younger generations? Members of the Elder Wisdom Circle are seniors who share their wisdom with young advice seekers from across the world. Via the Internet, Elders answer advice requests at their own convenience, offering young readers personalized and free advice on a wide range of topics - love and relationships, family and child-rearing, career and self-improvement, and more. Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, the Elder Wisdom Circle has more than 600 Elders (aged 60 to 105) across North America. The EWC program and our Elders have been featured on ABC, BBC, CBS, FOX, NPR and in such publications as Glamour, the LA Times, Ladies Home Journal, Real Simple, Time & USA Today. We are one of the largest providers of personal advice, with hundreds of thousands of readers. We are looking for seniors in your area to help expand our national reach. Please visit our site at www.ElderWisdomCircle.org and then the 'Offer Advice' tab on the top of the homepage. All advice providers must be 60 or better, no exceptions. Volunteers must complete an application and screening process.
08831.title: Monroe Township>>>Advice Counselor

10162.description: Simply by using your vehicle you can save animals - Volunteer your time to transport animals along what is called a \"Rescue Relay Transport\". Each week there are hundreds of animal rescue transports taking place where animals are moved from high-kill shelters to no-kill shelters and rescue organizations, as well as foster homes and adopters. It's easy for you to get involved and help save more animals simply by driving a leg in this relay. How it works: 1. Sign-up on Doobert.com or use the Facebook plug-in (search for \" Doobert Rescue\" on Facebook) and specify the days you're available, the distance you're willing to drive, and then sit back and we'll do the rest. 2. When an animal rescue organization posts a transport request, the system will automatically search to see if it matches your profile (if you're available and within the distance) and then it automatically sends you an e-mail. 3. Then you simply click on the leg that you can cover and everyone else will see that you've signed up for that leg. 4. You'll get communications from the transport coordinator and, once the transport is a \"go\", you simply drive to the meeting place, load up the animals, and drive them to the next meeting place to hand them off to the next volunteer. You'll get plenty of doggy kisses and thank you's along the way as the animals know you are there to help them. There are videos on www.doobert.com that walk you through the process and give you tips and tricks on how to do transport. It's simple - and we need volunteers across the country, so share with your friends and help save an animal today!
10162.title: Drive a leg – Save a life! - New York, NY

10162.description: Loaning an animal your couch can save their life! - Every 16 seconds an animal is euthanized simply due to overpopulation. Shelters do not have unlimited space and unfortunately have to make room. Rescue groups do not have the facilities and rely on fosters to help. Simply by agreeing to foster you can save an animal’s life. ARF’s German Shepherd Rescue is partnering with Doobert.com, the leading online forum for animal rescues, animal shelters and volunteers, to help get more foster homes for rescue animals. How it works: 1. Sign up on Doobert.com or use the Facebook plug-in (search for \"Doobert Rescue\" on Facebook) and build your foster profile for how you can help foster animals. You get to pick the type, duration and tell potential shelters and rescues about your situation. It’s up to you what information you share. 2. We allow approved animal welfare organizations (Shelters and Rescues) to search for volunteers like you, based upon distance and your foster profile. They can see the information you’ve shared and reach out to you if there is a match. 3. You’ll be contacted by them directly and can determine if you are able to help that particular organization with fostering either overnight, short-term or longer-term. It’s up to you whether you help when you’re contacted. You'll get plenty of doggy and kitty kisses and thank you's along the way as the animals know you are there to help them. And there are many more ways to help volunteer to save animals on Doobert.com. It's simple and we need volunteers across the country - so share with your friends, family, and co-workers and help save an animal today!
10162.title: Let me crash on your couch… please? - New York, NY

10162.description: Pilots to the Rescue is seeking active and inactive pilots to help save animals. Even if you lost your medical, are not able to be PIC, or just can't afford to fly regularly, we need pilots to help coordinate animal rescue transport flights for other pilots that are transporting animals. Did you know that every 16 seconds in the U.S. an animal is euthanized due to overpopulation? Animal Rescues and Shelters do their best to move the animals to safety but need volunteers to transport the animals to their forever homes. Pilots to the Rescue is partnering with Doobert.com to manage these transport requests to get the animals where they need to go. For longer distances it’s more ideal to have pilots involved, but to plan these requests you need to have a working knowledge of General Aviation airports, how weight & balance works, and how to incorporate volunteer pilots’ needs into the transport request. You don’t even have to leave your home. All you need is a computer and a phone and we’ll train you how to do it. How it works: Let us know you can help by responding to this post! We’ll send you information to get up to speed on being a volunteer pilot, or training videos to be a coordinator. If you're interested in being a coordinator we'll get you connected with a Rescue or Shelter to plan the transports. That’s it! And we’ll be here to support you all along the way. It's simple and we always need more volunteers (drivers, pilots, photographers, fosters, etc.) across the country, so share with your friends, family and co-workers and help us save an animal today!
10162.title: Punch holes in the sky & save animals! - Pilots Wanted! - New York, NY

10162.description: We need animal rescue transport coordinators to help organize rescue transports. So whether you are retired, not able to travel, or just looking for a way to save animals, we need you! Did you know that every 16 seconds in the U.S. an animal is euthanized due to overpopulation? Animal Rescues and Shelters do their best to move the animals around but need volunteers to transport the animals to their forever homes. Rescues and Shelters use Doobert.com to create their transport requests to get the animals where they need to go, but we need volunteer transport coordinators to help set up and manage the trip. You don’t even have to leave your home. All you need is a computer and a phone and we’ll train you how to do it. How it works: Let us know you can help by responding to this post! We’ll connect you with one of our experienced transport coordinator volunteers to set up time to get you trained on the Doobert.com system. When there’s a transport request, we’ll connect you with the requesting organization to help them effectively plan and manage their transport. That’s it! And we’ll be here to support you all along the way. It's simple and we always need more volunteers (drivers, pilots, photographers, fosters, etc.) across the country, so share with your friends, family and co-workers and help us save an animal today!
10162.title: Do you have a computer and a phone?  You can save animals! - New York, NY

10162.description: We need pilots to help coordinate animal rescue transport flights for other pilots that are transporting animals. So whether you are a current pilot, retired pilot or you lost your medical, we still need you! Did you know that every 16 seconds in the U.S. an animal is euthanized due to overpopulation? Animal Rescues and Shelters do their best to move the animals around but need volunteers to transport the animals to their forever homes. Rescues and Shelters use Doobert.com to create their transport requests to get the animals where they need to go. For longer distances, it’s more ideal to have pilots involved but to plan these requests you need to have a working knowledge of General Aviation airports, how weight & balance works, and how to incorporate volunteer pilots’ needs into the transport request. You don’t even have to leave your home. All you need is a computer and a phone and we’ll train you how to do it. How it works: Let us know you can help by responding to this post! We’ll connect you with one of our experienced transport coordinator volunteers to set up time to get you trained on the Doobert.com system. When there’s a transport flight request we’ll connect you with the requesting organization to help them effectively plan and manage their flight. That’s it! And we’ll be here to support you all along the way. It's simple and we always need more volunteers (drivers, pilots, photographers, fosters, etc.) across the country, so share with your friends, family and co-workers and help us save an animal today!
10162.title: Are you a pilot?  Then you can save animals! - New York, NY

10562.description: The Baby Box Project: Open Door Family Medical Centers delivers 450 babies a year. That's almost 40 new babies born each month. We know that our new parents often lack essential \"baby basics\" and the Baby Box initiative is a response to this problem. The actual box becomes a bassinet, and we add baby essentials, as well as coupons for Health and Wellness classes, prenatal and post-partum classes, and prenatal support with our Patient Advocates. Please host a Baby Essential Drive: We can use your help to collect: Sleep sacks (non-swaddling) or Layette gowns, newborn or size small Infant Thermometer or Infant Health Kit Bilingual Baby Book Diapers size 1 Wipes Diaper Rash Cream Infant Toy Outfits, Onesies, Sleep & Play: newborn or 3 months We need about 40 of each item, each month. Please consider hosting a drive at your organization, office, faith-based organization, school or just donate to help a new baby have a better start. https://www.opendoormedical.org/foundation/events/babybox Individual donations are appreciated and can be taken to any Open Door health center during all business hours. We would love for groups or organizations to consider adopting a month! For drives or larger donations our collection space is in Ossining and delivers would be really appreciated! Please contact Alicia Ward at 914-502-1468 or email award@odfmc.org. If you are interested, we host baby box assembly days at our Ossining and Port chester locations. Ossining is typically the first Monday of each month from 9:30am - until finished or 12:00pm and Port Chester is the second Monday of each month from 12:30pm - until finished or 3:00pm. please contact Alicia Ward.
10562.title: Baby Essential Drive
10562.org: Open Door Family Medical Centers Inc

10562.description: Open Door Family Medical Centers participates in Reach Out and Read a national literacy program designed for medical offices. The goal is to help promote preschool literacy for children living in poverty and help them become more kindergarten ready. It is so simple, volunteers and doctors alike read aloud to our young patients, provide tips for parents to read with their child and give them a book to take home to promote reading at home. The national Reach Out and Read program states that p arents served by Reach Out and Read are up to four times more likely to read aloud to their child. Many of the families Open Door serves speak Spanish as the first language in the home. We would love to make bilingual books available for these families. Our volunteers can read to the child in English at the health center and the families can read to their child at home in Spanish. Our goal is to collect 200 Bilingual English-Spanish children's board books and picture books for each of our 5 health centers. That 1,000 books. Gently used books are welcome. Can you host a book drive to support the young patients at Open Door? Individual donations are also welcome. Please contact Alicia Ward at award@odfmc.org for more information or a book drive flier to use.
10562.title: Bilingual English-Spanish Children's Book Drive
10562.org: Open Door Family Medical Centers Inc

10562.description: Literacy Champion: Book Donation Manger Open Door Family Medical Centers participates in a national reading program, Reach Out and Read. The mission is to better prepare preschool children living in poverty to enter kindergarten by getting them excited about reading and educating their parent about the importance of reading aloud to their child. Book donation manager. We receive many book donations and need one or two people to: Sort the books when they come in Box by books type such as board books for toddlers, easy picture books, picture books, Step-into-Reading, easy chapter books & older chapter books. Occasionally pick up books drives from our health centers or other locations in Westchester. The book storage is located at Ossining Open Door. The other health centers are located in Sleepy Hollow, Port Chester, Mt. Kisco and Brewster. Books for our Brewster location can be delivered there or left at our Port Chester site for a staff member to bring. Notes: This would be a great volunteer position for two or three friends to take on! You need to be in good physical condition. The book storage is in the basement, so would not be great for someone with many allergies. Volunteer would need to use their own vehicle. Book sorting and drop offs would be your choice of day(s) Monday - Thursday, between 9:30am - 5:00pm Application Requirements: Complete an online Volunteer Application and if accepted, part 2 of the online Volunteer Application. All volunteers 18 years and older will have a background check performed by Open Door Medical requirements: Provide documentation of a physical exam and PPD Test (TB) not older than 12 months Provide an immunization record or documentation of blood work for titer levels Provide documentation of the seasonal flu vaccine Sign a Hepatitis B form Have two reference forms completed and submitted directly to Open Door Complete an online volunteer orientation. Complete an online safety post-test and a volunteer orientation post-test. Sign a Volunteer Service Agreement and Pledge of Confidentiality. Volunteers agree to serve a minimum of 20 hours in a 12 month period. Please contact Alicia Ward, Open Door Volunteer Coordinator with any questions: award@odfmc.org / 914-502-1468
10562.title: Literacy Champion: Book Donation Managers
10562.org: Open Door Family Medical Centers Inc

10562.description: Children who grow up with books from an early age are more prepared for kindergarten and do better in school. Please donate chubby board books for toddlers and children's picture books for preschool children! Open Door Family Medical Centers' Reach Out and Read program brings literacy to our young patients right in our waiting areas. The goal of the program is to work with children from 6 months old to 5 years old to help them be comfortable and excited about books and help them be better prepared to enter kindergarten and for life. The program is gear towards children living in poverty who have less access to have books in their home. Our reading volunteers help the children can select a book to take home each time they are at Open Door. We are in continual need chubby board books for our young patients. Please consider hosting a book drive to collect books four our youngest little patients. Contact Alicia Ward at award@odfmc.org. We have a 'How To' pamphlet if needed. Our volunteer readers program uses gently used books to read aloud with the children and help the family select a books to take home to promote reading at home. Our doctor's program uses new developmentally appropriate books during well visit from ages 6 months to 5 eyars old. Our Reach Out and Read program is part of the National Reach Out and Read program.
10562.title: Toddler Board Book Drive - We really need your help!
10562.org: Open Door Family Medical Centers Inc

11229.description: The main function of an office volunteer is to provide the office with assistance and support. This includes but is not limited to the following: Tasks include filing, mailings, making copies, compiling admission packets, other packets used by hospice field staff and other staff assistance depending on the individual expertise and qualifications.
11229.title: Office Volunteer
11229.org: Caring Hospice Services of New York

11229.description: Hospice volunteers: Visit patients in their homes and in facilities offering companionship and a chance to reminisce Read books, newspapers and other favorites to people when they aren’t able themselves Assist with small errands for the patient and family. Share their talents and gifts... Play Music, sing, draw at bedside of patient, create photo albums, knitt blankets and more. Provide patient the opportunity to tell his/her life story through the use of video, (if patient or caregiver has one available), audio and/or the written word. Office Volunteers assist office staff with basic tasks such as copying and filing, helping with web research, spreadsheets and more. Contribute to volunteer newsletter keeping volunteers and staff in tune with the Hospice Volunteer Program’s activities.
11229.title: Hospice Field Volunteer
11229.org: Caring Hospice Services of New York

07410.description: Join our team of volunteers. Participate in our engaging and flexible volunteer program. Help play a key role in supporting terminally ill patients and their loved ones. You CAN decide which program you want to be a part of: Administrative Volunteers Basic Clerical Tasks, such as Filing and Data Entry Become familiarized with Homecare Homebase software Work on Special Projects when needed Companion Volunteers Contribute to our patients' quality of life Visit patients in facilities in an area near you Read to patients, share special talents, play games, watch TV, and much more Benefits Increase purpose and meaning in your life by positively impacting other lives Experience significant opportunities for personal growth and development Convenient FREE training that fits your schedule Internship Credit (if applicable) Develop interpersonal skills Build your resume Reference Letter after a period of commitment Join our team of volunteers who make a difference!!
07410.title: Hospice/Healthcare Volunteers Needed - Fair Lawn, Ridgewood Area

07410.description: If you have an hour or more per week to give, Ascend Hospice welcomes your gifts of time and compassion. Whether you choose to work directly with patients and families or to volunteer in one of many other ways, you can make a profound difference in someone's life, including your own. Volunteers are an integral part of the hospice team. Volunteer Opportunities: Companionship Volunteers work directly with patients providing companionship, offering friendly visits, reading to patients, writing letters, offering a gentle touch or sharing a quiet moment. Complementary Volunteers are certified/trained professionals who can provide complementary modalities of reflexologly, music, Reiki, & massage. Pet Therapy Volunteers provide companionship from our certified therapy dogs. Administrative Volunteers provide help in our Cranford office by assisting with typing, addressing cards, organizing newsletters, creating packets, collating manuals and other varied clerical duties Craft Volunteers consist of individuals or groups who touch patients in a special way by making lap blankets, shawls, memory bears and other articles for patients to enjoy. Bereavement Volunteers offer support to the families of patients who have passed. During the grieving process the bereavement volunteer can be a valuable resource, especially for those who lack a solid support network. They often make phone calls to check up on family members and also send cards of comfort and care. Ascend Hospice serves counties throughout New Jersey. Areas where you are needed include: Atlantic County, Bergen County, Cape May County, Essex County, Hudson County, Mercer County, Middlesex County, Monmouth County, Morris County, North Passaic County, Ocean County, Somerset County, South Passaic County, Burlington County, Camden County and Union County. For more information about our free volunteer training and available opportunities, call our Volunteer Department or visit our website at Ascendhospice.com! We look forward to hearing from you! do NOT contact me with unsolicited services or offers
07410.title: Companionship Volunteer for Hospice

07410.description: Ascend Hospice is seeking Reiki practitioners to volunteer their time to those in their community. Reiki can assist with pain management, anxiety, emotional release and much more and is a wonderfil modality to use during end of life care. Hospice training is provided.
07410.title: Reiki Volunteer for Hospice

07410.description: Patients on Hospice really appreciate music! Won't you share you gifts and talents with others? Music therapy is beneficial to all persons who have functional deficits in physical, psychological, cognitive or social functioning. Research results and clinical experiences attest to the viability of music therapy even in those who are resistive to other treatment approaches. Music is a form of sensory stimulation, which provokes responses due to the familiarity, predictability, and feelings of security associated with it.
07410.title: Music Therapy for Hospice

07410.description: Ascend Hospice is seeking Pet Therapy Volunteers for our hospice patients. Pet therapy provides numerous benefits like encouraging movement and physical stimulation and it provides mental benefits like socialization, mental stimulation, companionship, and unconditional love. Please consider sharing your loving pet with us and bring some much needed smiles. Pets must be certified as therapy animals by an organization like TDI Therapy Dogs International- see website here http://www.tdi-dog.org/.
07410.title: Pet Therapy for Hospice - Fair Lawn

07410.description: Do you have wisdom to share? Are you 60 or better and enjoy offering guidance to younger generations? Members of the Elder Wisdom Circle are seniors who share their wisdom with young advice seekers from across the world. Via the Internet, Elders answer advice requests at their own convenience, offering young readers personalized and free advice on a wide range of topics - love and relationships, family and child-rearing, career and self-improvement, and more. Based in the San Francisco Bay Area, the Elder Wisdom Circle has more than 600 Elders (aged 60 to 105) across North America. The EWC program and our Elders have been featured on ABC, BBC, CBS, FOX, NPR and in such publications as Glamour, the LA Times, Ladies Home Journal, Real Simple, Time & USA Today. We are one of the largest providers of personal advice, with hundreds of thousands of readers. We are looking for seniors in your area to help expand our national reach. Please visit our site at www.ElderWisdomCircle.org and then the 'Offer Advice' tab on the top of the homepage. All advice providers must be 60 or better, no exceptions. Volunteers must complete an application and screening process.
07410.title: Bergen>>>Advice Counselor

07417.description: Ascend Hospice is seeking certified Reiki practioners to serve our end of life population in finding comfort, relaxation and peace during their final time with us. Your assistance is needed with reducing anxiety, relieving pain and providing a safe, comfortable environment. Training provided for volunteers.

07417.description: Ascend Hospice Music Volunteers are volunteers who specialize in sharing songs or instrumental music with patients and their loved ones. Whether the Music Volunteer is sharing an existing musical skill or playing music via the radio or digital device, the goal is to enhance the quality of life of our patients. Often, regularly scheduled visits are requested, however Music Volunteers may also be asked to provide musical visits on an occasional basis for one patient/family or for a group of patients at a facility as outreach for the local hospice agency. Hospice is built on the philosophy that we care for our patients ; mind, body and soul.

11530.description: About Are you interested in a field that works closely with individuals who have intellectual and developmental disabilities? Would you like to share your interests with someone who enjoys it just as much as you? Partners Health Plan, a not for profit health plan that supports the lives of individuals with developmental and intellectual disabilities, is looking for volunteers for The PAL Program. The PAL Program discovers a member’s passion, interests, and matches up the individual with a person or place in the community sharing a similar passion or interest. We discover what you enjoy and how it could potentially match with a member of PHP. Member Information 46 year old male who would like to be more active and enjoys taking walks around the mall but would love to do this with someone! He has mild intellectual disability, and loves cars and has an appreciation for old country music. How does it work? Meet with individual once a week, or once bi-weekly depending on schedule flexibility First outing will always be accompanied by Community Resource Coordinator Provide your own transportation to meet the individual at the destination Report to community resource coordinator with updates on the progress of outings Form natural friendship with individual based on similar interests Benefits Receive an optional professional reference upon completion of program Join an incredible community of passionate staff and volunteers Hours: Approximately one a week depending on the activity and volunteer schedule Suggested Commitment: 6 months - 1 year PHP provides equal opportunity for all volunteers.
11530.title: Mall Walker

11530.description: The Cradle of Aviation Museum has multiple needs: coordinating outreach problems to the local schools on LI, handling scout programs, running family activities on spring breaks & weekends, participating in special events and competitions,after school programs, camps, clerical research and developing school programs, activities, etc. OR become involved as a Leader to help manage the diverse programs that we have, over see department needs such as training, scheduling and coordinating activities.
11530.title: Love kids and learning through "fun"?...Help us help them at the Museum! Volunteer with the Educatio

11530.description: Handling various programs within the Cradle of Aviation Museum: discovery carts, space flight center, museum demos, learning labs, family activities, special events and competitions, after school programs, camps, saturday classes, scouts! We handle over 250,000 visitors a year and 50,000 students during the school calendar. We could use the help of people who are ambitious, creative, flexible and enthusiastic about helping and educating the public!!
11530.title: Public Programs for Education Department at the Museum

11530.description: The Education Department is looking for individuals who are flexible, motivated and enthusiastic about teaching students and working with school groups. Guided education gallery tours, museum classes, afterschool programs, outreach programs,staffing artifact carts,grant writing and scout programs are the opportunities that we have here. Minimum volunteer requirement is four hours per week. If you are ambitious and ready to use your experiences and creativity to impact hundreds of teachers and students visiting the Museum,you are ready to be an Education Teaching Volunteer. Teaching experience not required as we will train you.
11530.title: Education Teaching Volunteers

11530.description: The Cradle of Aviation is looking for part-time, volunteer teachers. The museum presents a variety of programs to school groups, as well as fun family weekend activities, camps during the summer and vacation breaks, scout programs, discovery stations, outreach and more. Volunteer for one or more of these activities. Candidates should have good public speaking skills and be enthusiastic and energetic. Experience in teaching not necessary!!
11530.title: Education Volunteer

07730.description: The Turner Syndrome Foundation has the perfect opportunity for you! Obtain practical office experience and work with a team of talented people to help others and to do good! Brush up on your skills, use new technology, and help make the world a better place. If you are new to the job market or have been out of workforce for a while and looking for re-entry, join our team as a volunteer. Your experience with this national nonprofit promises to be a solid resume and confidence builder. Telephone & clerical Microsoft Office Research Writing Event planning Customer service Social work Education Advocacy Marketing Social media Fundraising Our goal is to find 3-4 people for part-time or full-time engagement to drive this mission forward. Please apply today!
07730.title: Office Help Needed!

07009.description: Description Use what you have learned in the classroom to help improve the quality of life for hospice patients. Utilize free time to be compassionate and genuine in order to reduce terminally ill patients’ loneliness and isolation. Please help us keep our patients happy and comfortable as they reach the end of their life due to a variety of health conditions including: cancer, Alzheimer’s, etc. How can you benefit by being a volunteer? Build your resume: Volunteer experience shows proof of motivation, commitment, initiative, dependability, and flexibility Develop interpersonal skills Increase meaning and purpose in your life Experience significant opportunities for growth and development Responsibilities of Companion volunteers: Contribute to our patients' quality of life Attend to Patients' Needs Communicate with Nurses by keeping them Up to Date about each Patient visited Maintain Patients' Confidentiality Travel and Visit patients in facilities in an area near you Read to them, give hand massage, assist in life review or memory building We offer you: FREE TB test and MMR Titer Extremely flexible assignments (anytime you can give is greatly appreciated) Convenient Orientation and FREE training and that fits your schedule Receive Internship Credit (if applicable-unpaid)
07009.title: Great Opportunity for Healthcare Students

07002.description: We are are a 501 c 3 nonprofit and are planning to purchase a one (1) family house here in Bayonne, NJ 07002. We do not have much much money for downpayment. We need somebody who can guide us in this including where we can save and inspection of the property. We invite you to visit our website: thecheerfulgiver.info/thecheerfugliver.org.
07002.title: Realtor/Property Specialist/Property Inspector

Excellent area for volunteers looking to explore potential career choice in therapy related fields. Responsibilities include organizing/straightening closets/shelves in treatment rooms. Clean/returns toys to proper locations. Assists therapists with set-up/clean-up of activities. Performs necessary office/clerical tasks including copying, filing and organizational tasks. Assists therapist with engaging patients in play activities.

07003.description: Be a Literacy Volunteer Share the Gift of Reading, Writing, and Speaking English Literacy Volunteers of America, Essex & Passaic Counties (LVA), is a non-profit organization dedicated to helping adults improve their ability to speak, read, and write English. As an LVA volunteer, you can help people achieve a more rewarding life through weekly tutoring in reading, writing, and speaking English. We have a long list of students waiting for help. Our students are comprised both of English speakers who need help becoming proficient at reading and writing, and speakers of other languages who need help learning English. The first step to becoming an LVA tutor is to register for one of Tutor-Training Workshops. Please visit our website at www.lvaep.org or call 973-566-6200, ext 217 for more details. \"Literacy is a bridge from misery to hope.\" Kofi Annan
07003.title: Share Your Gift of Literacy
07003.org: Literacy Volunteers of America, Essex and Passaic Counties

07003.description: Give the Gift of Literacy to adults seeking to learn how to read and write English. LVA is currently accepting applications from adult volunteers from the community to serve on our Board of Trustees. Board members are responsible for setting the Goals and Policies of the organization, developing the Annual Plan, approving and monitoring the Annual Budget, hiring and evaluating the Executive Director, and for overseeing the management of the organization. This adult literacy organization has been serving the Essex County and now also the Passaic County communities since the 1980’s. It trains volunteer adults to tutor other adults in Basic Literacy and English as a Second Language. Our students realize remarkable personal achievements, like Andrea, named Literacy New Jersey's 2015 \"Student of the Year;\" Barry, an Army reservist who served in Iraq and Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, and won the first-place prize for fiction writing in the 2016 New Jersey Association for Lifelong Learning Adult Learner Writing Contest; and Barry, Fernanda and Beralia, our other writing contest winners. Our efforts have been recognized by organizations like Literacy New Jersey, which named LVA Essex & Passaic Counties the \"Outstanding Affiliate\" of 2015. If you would be interested in working with and helping this dynamic, established organization to continue to grow and serve our multicultural community, please complete the \"Prospective Board Member Profile\" @ http://www.lvaep.org/forms.html and email it to Board Development Committee at srice@lvaep.org. The Board usually meets bimonthly, September through June, on Monday evenings at the East Orange Public Library in Essex County. Prior board experience would be beneficial but not required. Most important is your desire to help us share the gift of literacy with all adults seeking to acquire or improve their English language skills to attain their own personal, educational, and career goals.
07003.title: Serve as Board of Trustees with LVA, Essex & Passaic Counties, NJ
07003.org: Literacy Volunteers of America, Essex and Passaic Counties

07003.description: Reporting to the Operations and Finance Manager, the administrative assistant will perform a range of administrative and office support functions for Mary’s Meals USA to facilitate the efficient operation of the organization. The administrative assistant will directly contribute to increasing Mary’s Meals USA’s capacity to provide the most effective help to those suffering the effects of extreme poverty in the world’s poorest communities helping children receive one daily meal in their place of education. Duties and Responsibilities: Handle incoming phone calls, emails and written correspondence, providing prompt responses and forwarding to appropriate staff member where necessary. Perform general clerical duties. Handle requests for information and data and follow up with appropriate staff member. Manage office supply inventories and coordinate maintenance of office equipment. Assist the Operations and Finance Manager in the management and administration of related projects. Assist with volunteer and outreach coordination as required. Ensures that all printed materials are in stock and ensures proper presentation of materials for distribution. Provides support in the coordination and distribution production Mary’s Meals USA materials. Qualifications: Excellent organizational, written and verbal skills Detail oriented and committed to meeting deadlines Good interpersonal skills Works well independently and as part of a team Ability to adapt to shifting priorities and manage multiple deadlines Ability to problem-solve Knowledge of Microsoft Office programs
07003.title: Volunteer Administrative Assistant

07003.description: Welcome to the ASD Climber Foundation! ASD stands for Autism Spectrum Disorders. We are working with a family in your area with a child on the autism spectrum. The family wants to train volunteers to help them run a home based social skills program called the Son-Rise Program. No experience necessary. Free training provided. Time commitment is 2-4 hours a week for 6 months or more. PLEASE READ: After completing the \"I want to help\" page, you will immediately receive an auto reply email with our Volunteer Profile. Please fill this out, and we will forward it directly to the family in your area that requires help. ***please add asdclimberfoundation@me.com to your safe list and check your junk mail if you do not see an immediate response in your inbox*** Thank you for your time!
07003.title: Bloomfield, NJ: Autism Volunteer

07004.description: PLACEMENT PURPOSE The Fiscal Reviewer is part of a team of about 8 people who review each of the cases opened for clients after a fire. Normally it takes only a few minutes to check each case and certify that it meets the requirements for financial assistance; however, there are times the Team Member must get in contact with the Manager in charge of the county where the fire was, to get information corrected before the case can be passed through. OPEN TIME DAYS There are four 3 hour shifts each day, Monday through Friday; however, you don’t have to be available during the full hours, unless we are trying to meet a deadline. Shifts needed now are 9 to noon and/or noon to 3. REQUIRED TRAINING Disaster Cycle Services: An Overview Recovery Services: An Overview Direct Client Assistance Fundamentals Casework & Recovery Planning Fundamentals Meet the Client: What is a Family? Two Youtube videos (optional): Creating a Case and Recovery Planning Familiarization with a  job tool : ｠Fiscal Review Job Tool After you’ve finished the training, you will work with the Team Manager one on one to make sure you understand the whole process.｠ Once you are comfortable, you can take a couple shifts, always being able to communicate with the Manager if you have｠questions. ｠｠

07004.description: PLACEMENT PURPOSE The American Red Cross Disaster Cycle Services (DCS) is launching the Home Fire Preparedness Campaign (HFPC) in October 2014. Its goal is to reduce the rate of deaths and injuries due to home fires by 25 percent over 5 years. Its strategy includes participating in a community coalition that targets neighborhoods at-risk for home fires; installs and tests smoke alarms; and provides fire safety and disaster preparedness education/planning. This position exists primarily to appropriately install new smoke alarms or batteries in working smoke alarms and to test them. It is part of a smoke alarm home visit team. OPEN TIME DAYS - 5-10 hours per weekend, once a quarter on average - Weekdays REQUIRED TRAINING American Red Cross Volunteer Orientation Disaster Services: An Overview Home Fire Preparedness Campaign Guidance and Training: Safety for Home Visists, Smoke Alarm Installation , and other required training.
