11217.description: We are currently seeking 1-2 people to help us out with the following for our Parents support group of children being affected by cancer: 1. Assist with securing new Support Group sponsors 2. Communicate with vendors to secure deliverables, gift certificates and logos to properly thank them on social media 3. Attend support group events to establish a relationship with parents and care takers to improve retention of participants. 4. Assist with securing meeting and or event space. 5. Keep a running list of attendees to inform them of upcoming activities.
11217.title: Administration Volunteer

11217.description: A Free Bird (AFB) is a 501(c)3), nonprofit art therapy organization dedicated to helping young people with cancer explore the artist within, by inspiring, teaching and celebrating them as artists. Founded in 2011, our organization remains 100% volunteer. Please take a moment to visit our website, www.afreebird.org to gain a better understanding of who we are and what we do. AFB is at an exciting transformational moment as we move into the next stage of growth. What began as a startup is developing into a national and international movement with the capacity to encourage, nurture and uplift children with cancer and other debilitating and life threatening diseases the world over. We have many ideas, plans and projects that we’d like to execute and launch this year, including a couple capital projects that involve a new home for the organization in an abandoned theatre, and setting up a branch office is Israel, among others. We are challenged to create a fundraising and development operation that will provide the annual revenue and a depth of support we need to ensure that our programs and organization are supported and sustained over the short and long term. The organization’s leadership is deeply committed to its fundraising success. To this end, the Board seeks a part-time, volunteer Director of Development to join our organization for the long term. At the end of the first year, a commission can be negotiated. The successful candidate must have an authentic passion for our mission, excellent management skills, demonstrated success as an engaging fundraiser and a highly articulate communicator, skilled at making a compelling case for support both on paper and in person. Ideally, here’s what we would like in our Director of Development: An established leader with at least 10-15 years of senior development experience with demonstrable achievements, both financial and operational Proven ability to build, manage, mentor, motivate, and hold accountable to high standards, a diverse volunteer team, located in remote locations A commitment to excellence and success in increasing the effectiveness of development staff through established objectives and methods Expertise in strategic and operational resource development planning (both short and long-term); demonstrated success in executing broad fundraising strategies Proven ability to personally develop strategies, cultivate, solicit and steward major and institutional donors at the six and seven-figure levels; the ability to inspire high-net worth individuals and major foundations to financial leadership Strong written and verbal communication skills, including grants writing, with an emphasis on the ability to persuade Creative and innovative, with entrepreneurial and strategic inclinations A Bachelor’s degree; advanced degree preferred Commitment to working 20-hours per week (minimum of 10) Commitment to volunteering a minimum of one year with AFB How to apply : please send your CV along a brief cover letter stating the reason for your interest, your ability to commit your time, and what you hope to receive in return. AFB does not discriminate on the basis of gender, age, race, ethnicity, national origin, creed, sexual orientation, disability, or any other status protected by law.
11217.title: Development Director

11217.description: Hello! Brooklyn Workforce Innovations offers free Low-Voltage Cable installation training with it's Brooklyn Networks program. For 2017, we have just one class left, and it will begin July 21st! Deadline for applications is July 11th. We have just 5 weeks of recruitment left, and o ur goal is to invite 30 dedicated applicants to try-outs so that we can select 16 students for our class. We are looking for 10-15 volunteers to do flyering out in the 5 boroughs of NYC from 6/12-7/10. If you can volunteer 2 days a week for a 2-3 hours, that would be fantastic. If you can only volunteer for one day, that is great also. Target areas are: South Bronx, Harlem, Washington Heights, Brownsville, East New York, Jamaica-Queens, Canarsie, Red-Hook, & Gowanus. We are also looking to flyer on and around Public Housing/NYCHA. We are looking for volunteers who are energetic and want to spread the word! Please reply with some information about yourself and why you are interested in volunteering.

11217.description: Are you a successful and enthusiastic event planner? Are you ready to join a life-changing organization where your skills would go towards a meaningful cause? If so, YTC is looking for YOU! As an event planner, you will be responsible for planning events from conception through to completion. You will provide outstanding customer service and organize events that will impact the youth of our community. Responsibilities Plan, design and produce events while managing all project delivery elements within specified timeframes Liaise with other departments and external partners to identify needs to ensure customer satisfaction Organize facilities and manage all event details such as décor, entertainment, location, invite list, special guests, equipment, promotional material, etc. Collaborate with HR, Marketing and PR to promote events Identify and communicate staff requirements and coordinate their activities Proactively handle and resolve any emerging issues on the event day Conduct pre- and post- event evaluations and report on outcomes Provide feedback and periodic reports to management Research market, identify event opportunities and generate interest Competencies Excellent time management and communication skills Ability to manage multiple projects independently and efficiently (especially in the weeks leading up to an event) Strong organizational and collaborative skills Education and Experience Bachelor degree required Prior experience in a related function preferred Nonprofit sector experience a plus

11217.description: Gowanus In Unity Tutoring Program's basic goal is to give students individualized help with their schoolwork using volunteer tutors from the community. We feel that the one-on-one environment allows the tutor to get to know the student, and the student's academic needs. MOST IMPORTANT; Students and tutors learn from each other. Wyckoff Houses Community Center sponsors the tutoring program. All tutors will be fingerprinted for a background check by NYCHA and tutor will provide medical clearance including TB test. References and resumee are also required. Details: Each new volunteer tutor is interviewed to determine his or her areas of academic strength and interest. The Tutoring Coordinator, Steven Shooman, then matches the strengths, motivations, and availability of the potential tutors with the needs and personalities of the students who have applied. The tutor and the student decide on time, duration, and frequency of sessions. Most tutors meet their students once a week, with sessions lasting one hour. The tutor, student, and parent/guardian are encouraged to contact the Tutoring Coordinator if they have any problems or concerns they cannot resolve. The tutoring program culminates near the end of the school year.

07305.description: The Borgen Project is an innovative, national campaign that is working to make poverty a focus of U.S. foreign policy. This is a 12-week, part-time, unpaid internship. The selected candidate will be able to work from home and set their own schedule, but must meet weekly deadlines. Articles submitted will appear on BORGEN Magazine or The Borgen Project Blog. Key Responsibilities: - Interview sources and research topics in-depth. - Write 2 well-researched articles per week. - Communicate with editors and supervisors. - Assist with fundraising. Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Attend national conference call and/or training every Monday at 4 - 5:30 PM PST. Qualifications: Strong journalism writing skills. Must be able to work independently and meet deadlines with very little supervision. Experience writing for newspapers is helpful, but not required.

Create a personal fundraising campaign and meet targets. - Attend national conference call and/or training every Monday at 4 - 5:30 PM PST. Qualifications: Strong research and writing skills. Must be able to work independently and meet deadlines with very little supervision. Experience writing SEO friendly content is helpful, but not required.

The Borgen Project is hiring an HR Intern who will work remotely. This human resources role will focus on national recruitment and updating job postings. Key Responsibilities: - Update job postings (80% of internship). - Inform groups and classes of openings. - Take on various tasks as needed. - Everyone who is part of the organization assists the team with fundraising, 25-hours of this position is dedicated to creating and implementing a personal fundraising campaign. - Assist with advocacy efforts. Details: This is an unpaid internship, although college credit is available. The HR internship is 16-hours per week for 12-weeks. Key Responsibilities: - Create a branding campaign. - Conduct an informal focus group and gather feedback for market research. - Pitch story ideas to print, broadcast and digital media. - Create and implement a fundraising strategy. - Plan, market and present at an informational meeting. - Utilize social media and develop strategies for web-based messaging. - Assist with The Borgen Project's advocacy efforts. - Take on assignments as needed. Details: This is an unpaid internship, although college credit is available. The internship is 16-hours per week for 12-weeks. Must meet weekly deadlines and be available the first Monday evening of the month, at 5pm PST for meetings.

11215.description: We need your help to make our 2017 New York Lymphoma Walk a success! Volunteers are needed from 6:30am - 12:30pm on Sunday, July 9, 2017 at the Nethermead in Prospect Park. Volunteers are needed for the following areas: set-up t-shirt distribution registration food prep and distribution general clean-up Since 2003, the Lymphoma Research Founation (LRF) has raised over $20 million through its nationwide Active Lifestyle Events Program. The Lymphoma Walk is a non-competitive 5k walk where survivors, family, friends, community and corporate teams walk in honor and in memory of those whose lives have been touched by lymphoma. Funds raised by participants will supoort LRF's mission of eradicating lymphoma and serving those touched by this disease. **Event will happen rain or shine
11215.title: Volunteers Needed- 5k Walk in Prospect Park, Brooklyn

We're seeking volunteers to assist us on the day of event in: -Need- someone to film/ video event -Need-all volunteers to help in handing out snacks and drinks -Need- all volunteers to alert passer byes of the activities and hand out postcards to those who are interested in the organization. Also they should be prepared to take email details for those who would like further information to future events/ activities. -Need-a volunteer to help post to social media. -Need- a volunteer to monitor and time the event fitness challenge. 4-5 people will suffice Each volunteer will be supplied a tee-shirt representing foundation.

11215.description: You lead the way. Hospital buildings can be confusing places. Add on the fear and concern that may accompany a Hospital visit and it may be difficult for patients or visitors to easily find their way around. As a Trailblazer, you will ease some of the stress with a cheerful and welcoming demeanor and by providing help with navigating their way through NYM. You will provide clear verbal instructions and escort patients to different units, departments and sites as needed. You will also use direction sheets, maps and other resources to facilitate visits. Trailblazers play a key role in improving the NYM experience for patients and visitors alike. We would love to hear from you if you are: An effective communicator, give great attention to detail, enjoy providing excellent customer service, are cheerful and welcoming, can maintain a positive attitude, and have the ability to stand and walk for most of the shift Minimum Commitment: One three-hour shift a week for a minimum of six months. Times: Monday - Friday 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. Apply Now: Please submit an online application directly to us! You can access the application here: https://www.volgistics.com/ex/portal.dll/ap?AP=841357239 For more information, please visit us at www.nym.org
11215.title: Be a Trailblazer! Hospital Wayfinding Program

11215.description: Are you compassionate, caring and a good listener? Are you interested in facilitating the healthy development of children? Do you feel comfortable interacting with families with toddlers? Step by Step volunteers provide caregivers with information about developmental milestones to help parents keep track of their young child’s progress. Start a Conversation. Change a life. As a Step by Step volunteer at NYM you will foster one on one health literacy skills by teaching and empowering parents to recognize and track key developmental childhood milestones. You will make the most of pediatric clinic wait time by introducing child development charts and paving the way for important parent discussions with healthcare professionals. These small waiting room conversations can help identify big developmental issues and set families on the road to early intervention as needed. We would love to hear from you if you are: Compassionate, caring, outgoing, friendly, have knowledge and interest in the development of children Minimum commitment: One four-hour shift per week Times: Monday - Friday, 8:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m. How to Apply: Submit an online application here: https://www.volgistics.com/ex/portal.dll/ap?AP=841357239 Make sure that the schedule preferences you list match the available times listed above
11215.title: Step-by-Step: Parent Education in Pediatric Clinic

11215.description: Are you compassionate and outgoing? Do you enjoy problem-solving and working to contribute to high quality service? Ambassadors support patients and caregivers with the aim of making their overall Hospital experiences better. Help make connections that matter. Ambassadors may not be able to make the Hospital experience totally stressless, but they can contribute in ways that help patients and their families stress less. By proactively addressing questions, concerns and requests, Ambassadors complement and enhance the work of our medical staff. As a volunteer Ambassador, you will work to alleviate concerns by educating patients about staff resources, roles and responsibilities and by providing information on the Hospital as a whole. Through friendly conversations and bedside visits, you will support patients and their families with compassion and care, serving as an extra set of eyes and ears to create a high quality, patient centered experience. We would love to hear from you if you are: Compassionate, outgoing, able to focus on high quality service delivery, an effective communicator, attentive to details Minimum Commitment: One three-hour shift per week for a minimum of six months Times: Monday - Friday 2:00 p.m. - 5:00 pm or 5:00 p.m. - 8:00 p.m. How to Apply: Please fill out our online application here: https://www.volgistics.com/ex/portal.dll/ap?AP=841357239 Be sure that the schedule preferences you list match the times listed above. We look forward to hearing from you.
11215.title: Ambassador Program

11215.description: Be the face of a unique education nonprofit in Brooklyn by volunteering with 826NYC and the Brooklyn Superhero Supply Co. 826NYC is an education nonprofit that operates the Brooklyn Superhero Supply Co. to help fund its free tutoring and writing programs, which serve over 2,300 students a year. As a store volunteer, you'll be an ambassador for our programs and first line of communication with the outside community. You'll also have the opportunity to sell capes, secret identity kits, and cans of all kinds of superhero necessities--intelligence, invisibility, and gravity to name a few. You can assist shoppers as they use our Villain Containment facility, Cape Tester, and more. The store is open seven days a week, 11am-5pm, with morning and afternoon shifts available. Volunteers typically come by for an 11am-2pm or 2pm-5pm shift. If neither of those work, please get in touch regardless - the store can't operate without volunteers and we will work with your schedule.
11215.title: Be a superhero for literacy at the Brooklyn Superhero Supply Co.

11215.description: 826NYC hosts writing field trips where NYC public school students come into the center to write stories with our staff, volunteers, and one another. Field trips are always in need of enthusiastic volunteers up-front and behind the scenes to make the storytelling and writing experience come to life. We are always looking for new artists to live-illustrate our field trips, typists, and charismatic leaders to facilitate the writing process. If that's not your thing, or you're just more of the shy type, we'd love you to join our diligent behind-the-scenes printing and bookbinding team. Field trips take place most weekday mornings at our Park Slope center, from 10:00am to 12:30pm.
11215.title: Help NYC public school students create original stories

11215.description: 826NYC hosts after-school tutoring Monday through Thursday from 3:00pm-5:30pm in Park Slope and Williamsburg. Because it is a homework-help program, you will sometimes get to flex your writing skills, as well as your math, science, and history muscles. Don't worry if it's been a while since you've thought about the Pythagorean Theorem, though, staff and volunteers are always around to help! Tutoring offers the chance to give back to the community while also getting to know a bunch of awesome students and volunteers. Why not come check it out?
11215.title: Help NYC students as an After-School Tutor!

11215.description: Puppetry Arts, a Brooklyn based community arts non profit, is seeking new proactive, energetic, and resourceful individuals with a passion for the arts, community (and maybe puppetry) to join our team helping to expand programs, build revenue through a give/get program, and increase outreach. We welcome all ages 21yo and up that can proactivly support and participate in our organization. We meet via phone conferences twice a year. Each month board members recieve an email updating all activities Board Members are given a committee such as reviewing grants, fundraising, marketing etc... As a Board Member of our Charity, Puppetry Arts New York, you are NOT Liable for anything the organization does. All finances and programs are transparent are available at ChartiesNYS.com and the Charities Bureau. Check us out there or visit us at www.puppetryarts.org Bring to the organization what makes you great and the passion you have for cultural and civic opprtunties to our community. Please email us at info@puppetryarts.org and introduce yourself! www.puppetryarts.org
11215.title: Arts Organization Seeking Board Members

11215.description: Do you have a knack for connecting with children, enjoy playing games or have a flair for arts and crafts? Are you compassionate and patient? Peds Pals volunteers spend time with families on the pediatric unit, engaging children in fun activities while they are hospitalized. Make a difference any day of the week. What Kelly liked most about Tuesday was that she blew bubbles and put a puzzle together. What her parents liked was that they could see their four-year-old playing and giggling again. As a Peds Pals volunteer, you will bring more than board games and coloring books to the inpatient pediatric floor. You will bring the chance to create cheerful moments for families who often face long days of worrying and the challenge of entertaining a hospitalized child and their siblings. Whether playing at a young patient’s bedside or spending time in the pediatric playroom, Peds Pals volunteers can offer a bright source of comfort and a welcome break for parents. Our Inpatient Pediatric Unit admits patients from birth to age 21 allowing you to interact with a variety of ages. We would love to hear from you if you are: Energetic, compassionate, patient, comfortable around children of different ages, a positive thinker, able to be respectful of families during a difficult time Minimum Commitment: One shift per week for at least six months. Times:Seven days a week: 10:00 a.m.-12:00 p.m., 12:00 - 2:00 p.m., 2:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m., 6:00 - 8:00 p.m. How to apply: Submit an online application directly to NYM's Volunteer Department https://www.volgistics.com/ex/portal.dll/ap?AP=841357239 Be sure that your availability matches the availability listed above
11215.title: Peds Pals: Visit with children in our hospital!

11215.description: Reach Out and Read (ROR) is a national program in over 3,200 pediatric health care sites. Volunteer readers in ROR programs transform clinic waiting rooms into literacy-rich areas for children and parents, and help families learn the joys and the techniques of reading aloud. Volunteers read to children, modeling book-sharing techniques for parents and showing them by example that reading aloud is fun for parent and child. Volunteers come from all walks of life but have two important traits in common: a love of books and stories, and a genuine interest in helping children. We are looking for energetic and compassionate volunteers who are interested in fostering a love of reading in children at our site in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Requirements : Minimum Age: 18 Minimum Time Commitment: 2-4 hours a week Times: Monday-Friday 9am-12pm and or 1pm-4pm. To Apply An application can be completed at New York Methodist Hospital's website at www.nym.org. Click on \"About Us,\" and then \"Volunteer.\" Please take the time to fill out the on-line application. https://www.volgistics.com/ex/portal.dll/ap?AP=841357239 For more information call 718-780-5397 xt:101
11215.title: Reach Out And Read: Make reading fun

10035.description: We are currently accepting applications for Volunteer Dance Teachers for our Summer Program at Groove With Me, Inc. Groove With Me is a free dance school for girls in East Harlem. It engages girls during the idle out-of-school hours when 90% of youth violence occurs; and seeks to decrease teen pregnancy, truancy, crime, violence, prostitution, substance abuse and gang related activity. East Harlem has the highest unmet need for after school programming of any neighborhood in NYC. By volunteering you provide much needed out-of-school time safety - and arts programming. Summer Programming 2017 Schedule: Session 1 will run from July 5th - August 1st (4 weeks) Session 2 will run from August 2- August 22nd (3 weeks) If you are interested in this opportunity, please give me a call at 212-987-5910 or reach me via email at beatriz@groovewithme.org Beatriz Coronel, MA Program Director Groove With Me, Inc. 186 E 123rd St NY, NY 10035 Phone: 212-987-5910 Fax: 212-987-5080 www.groovewithme.org
10035.title: Volunteer Dance Teachers Needed for our Summer Program at Groove With Me, Inc.

10035.description: My name is Evelyn Garcia and I am writing you on behalf of The Way To Happiness Foundation. The Way To Happiness is a non-denominational movement reversing the decline and restoring to man, his integrity and trust. Comprised of 21 principles, The Way To Happiness is a moral code based wholly on common sense. More than 70 million copies of The Way To Happiness booklet have been distributed in over 130 countries. Because it is non-religious in nature it can be used as a tool to re-introduce moral values into the Court system, without violating the codes and laws which separate Church and State. The Way To Happiness booklet educates readers worldwide with a non-religious code which guides one to a better quality of life, restoring and nourishing those qualities such as tolerance, respect and forgiveness, which have been revered through the centuries. These principles can be followed by anyone of any race color or creed. The Way To Happiness principles have been successfully used to help improve family relations, increase tolerance in the workplace and even in the prison system which has noted a remarkable drop in the recidivism of offenders who have completed the program. The principles work to restore the bonds that unite mankind. For more information you may visit the foundation's website www.thewaytohappiness.org. For reservations or questions please contact Evelyn Garcia at 786-873-7718. I look forward to meeting with you and assisting you to guide people towards real solutions to their problems. Description The Way To Happiness: Because your survival is important to me. Happiness: N. A condition or state of well being, contentment, pleasure, joyful, untroubled existence, the reaction to having nice things happen to one. If one does not survive, no joy and no happiness are obtainable. Trying to survive in a chaotic (1) ,dishonest and generally immoral (2) society is difficult. Any individual seeks to obtain from life what pleasure and freedom from pain that they can. Your own survival can be threatened by the bad actions of others around you. Your own happiness can be turned to tragedy and sorrow by the dishonesty and misconduct of others. I am sure you can think of this actually happening. Such wrongs reduce one's survival and impair one's happiness. You are important to other people. You are listened to. You can influence others. The happiness or unhappiness of others you could name is important to you. Without too much trouble, using this book, you can help them survive and lead happier lives. While no one can guarantee that anyone else can be happy, their chances of survival and happiness can be improved. And with theirs, yours will be. It is in your power to point the way to a less dangerous and happier life. (1) Chaotic: having the character or nature of total disorder or confusion. (2) Immoral: Not moral; not following good practices of behavior; not doing right; lacking any idea of proper conduct. 1. TAKE CARE OF YOURSELF. 1-1 Get care when you are ill. 1-2 Keep your body clean. 1-3 Preserve your teeth. 1-4 Eat properly. 1-5 Get rest. 2. BE TEMPERATE 2-1 Do not do harmful drugs. 2-2 Do not take alcohol to excess. 3 DON'T BE PROMISCUOUS. (promiscuous: casual random sexual relations). 3-1 Be faithful to your sexual partner. 4. LOVE AND HELP CHILDREN. 5. HONOR AND HELP YOUR PARENTS. (Honor: to show respect for; to treat with deference and courtesy). 6. SET A GOOD EXAMPLE. 7. SEEK TO LIVE WITH THE TRUTH. 7-1 Do not tell harmful lies. 7-2 Do not bear false witness. 8. DO NOT MURDER. 9. DON'T DO ANYTHING ILLEGAL. 10. SUPPORT A GOVERNMENT DESIGNED AND RUN FOR ALL THE PEOPLE. 11. DO NOT HARM A PERSON OF GOODWILL. 12. SAFEGAURD AND IMPROVE YOUR ENVIRONMENT. 12-1 Be of good appearance. 12-2 Take care of your own area. 12-3 Help take care of the planet. 13. DO NOT STEAL. 14. BE WORTHY OF TRUST. 14-1 keep your word once given. 15. FUFILL YOUR OBLIGATIONS. 16. BE INDUSTRIOUS. (INDUSTRIOUS: applying oneself with energy to study or work; actively and purposely getting things done; opposite of being idle and accomplishing nothing. 17. BE COMPETENT 17-1 Look. See what you see, not what someone tells you that you see. 17-2 Learn. 17-3 Practice. 18 RESPECT THE RELIGIOUS BELIEFS OF OTHERS. 19 TRY NOT TO DO THINGS TO OTHERS THAT YOU WOULD NOT LIKE THEM TO DO TO YOU. 20. TRY TO TREAT OTHERS AS YOU WOULD WANT THEM TO TREAT YOU. Now what do you suppose would happen if one were to try to treat those around him with: Justness, loyalty, good sportsmanship, fairness, honesty, kindness, consideration, compassion, self-control, tolerance, forgiveness, benevolence, belief, respect, politeness, dignity, admiration, friendliness, love... and did it with integrity? 21. FLOURISH AND PROSPER.
10035.title: Help us teach others about Integrity, Morals and Values with a simple 21 precept guide!
10035.org: THE WAY TO HAPPINESS FOUNDATION INTERNATIONAL

10035.description: As of June 2017 we will complete 5 years of making science fun for hundreds of children all around NYC. To move forward on a firm foundation, we need a powerful and engaging Board of Directors. We are seeking dedicated skilled individuals to add to the Triple F Empowerment Inc board. We are specifically seeking candidates with nonprofit law knowledge/experience. Board members have the special privilege of helping raise much funds, attend monthly meetings and being a TFE ambassador. This is a special opportunity to play a key role in moving TFE to the next level and making SSC a premier STEAM education program. Applicants will be asked to send a resume, complete a volunteer application and participate in an person interview with our founder.
10035.title: Are you well versed in nonprofit law?- Join our Board of Directors

10035.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for volunteer tutors to provide academic support to Youth Action Youth Build for the Fall of 2017. We are currently seeking tutors for math to support students 18-24 years old as they prepare for the TASC, the new high school equivalency exam. You would work with a group of students for 3 hours per week between 9am to noon. (You can do this on one day.) This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience and who are interested in tutoring. In this role, you would collaborate with a local coordinator to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by experienced academic support professionals. To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor. Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have received a degree recently. Be willing to complete 11.5 hours of College Reading and Learning Aligned (CRLA) training at City College of New York. All tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Fall semester. We can accommodate your schedule if you cannot make the group trainings. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having tutors in these sessions early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about Youth Action Youth Build here: http://www.youthaction.nyc/
10035.title: Prepare 19-24 Year Olds in Math for High School Equivalency Exam in Fall 2017

10035.description: The Writers’ Room will serve 311 students in sixth through eighth grade with year-round, daily writing and literacy support. Our Writers’ Room will assist teachers in creating engaging and imaginative writing lessons that 826NYC volunteers will help to execute. So whether it’s sonnet-writing tied to a Shakespeare unit, lab-report writing for Science class, or music appreciation essays for the music curriculum, the 826NYC Writers’ Room will be there. Teachers will also be able to recommend struggling students come to the Writers’ Room for one-to-one support during their free periods or over their lunch hour. Volunteers will ensure that the students at MS 7 and Global Tech Prep receive the individualized support and feedback they need to become confident students and skilled writers. Projects and responsibilities include (but are not limited to): In-school tutoring, facilitating student workshops, and small group instruction Assisting with light (programs related) administrative work
10035.title: East Harlem Writers' Room Volunteer

We need childcare volunters to help with infants and toddlers while their mothers are in a Mother's Group. Dates needed: Fridays, from 19:30 - 12:30, from April 1 through May 8th Please contact the Volunteer Director at tgough@lsafhs.org to inquire further, along with your resume.
10035.title: Childcare Volunteers Needed Friday Mornings

10035.description: Love to cook and have some time to spare? Why not help us help the hungrY. Volunteer in our soup kitchen to help prep for and prepare meals. Contact us for more information on how you can delight the palates of the less fortunate.
10035.title: Chef Assistant Soup Kitchen

10035.description: Without the dedication and tireless enthusiasm of our volunteers, BHCCC could not provide services to the community. Volunteers are an integral part of our organization, and their contributions are invaluable and much appreciated. BHCCC offers a variety of volunteer opportunities for individuals, groups, companies, religious organizations, etc. On-Site Opportunities Unload & shelve food from the delivery trucks Pre-pack produce bags for pantry distribution Distribute grocery packages during our food pantry Serve lunch during our Soup Kitchen. Help with tasks such as mailings, data entry, filing and other clerical tasks.
10035.title: Help Us Help Those In Need

10035.description: Protect our environment and the special place in which we live! Citizens’ Climate Lobby (CCL) wants you! As a volunteer, you’ll be a member of the fastest growing and most effective climate advocacy group. You will work with concerned New York citizens to slow the effects of climate change. Let's work together to protect our beautiful ecosystems, livelihoods and way of life. Please respond to our posting for an invitation to learn more. You will: Meet with Congressional leaders. Write letters to the editors and op-eds. Meet with local media. Educate your community about global warming and legislative solutions. We provide: Monthly national conference calls with expert guest speakers. Weekly skill building sessions. On-line network with CCL volunteers across the U.S. National conference and lobby week in D.C. Volunteers commit to an average of 4-6 hours a month. Some of our volunteers dedicate more time than that. We hold no upper limit on your dedication to a stable climate and livable world. To learn more about us, please join an Introductory Conference Call. The next call is Wednesday at 5:00 p.m. Pacific/6:00 p.m. Mountain/7:00 p.m. Central/8:00 p.m. Eastern. This is an opportunity to learn about CCL. It is one hour, and there will be opportunities to ask questions. The conference call number is 1-866-642-1665, passcode 440699#.
10035.title: Sustainable Climate Environment Advocate New York City NY

10037.description: We are seeking enthusiastic, creative, industrious, responsible, punctual, and best of all, creative people who can generate fun every moment of the summer day camp experience. Depending upon your experience, you will work as Teacher, Head Counselor, or Group Leader in the classroom, in offsite locations, or in the gymnasium/outdoor playground. Must have tons of energy, a willingness to make a fool of yourself for the sake of making someone smile, the ability to give \"warm fuzzies\" on a daily basis, and a desire to have FUN! If you have experience in any of the following, this camp is for you: visual art, music, dramatic art, wacky science, coding, maker faire, financial literacy, entrepreneurship, community service, activism, literacy, education, chess, juggling, sports, yoga, firethrowing, marching band, drill team, gardening, cooking, learning, sharing love with children.
10037.title: Sunny Faces Welcome! Looking For Summer Camp Counselors - NYC

10037.description: We're looking for CodeSters who have the ability, fluidity, and patience to work with students between the ages of 6-16 with instruction on app development, website development, robotics, or game development. You will be on the cutting edge of teaching computer science concepts, as less than 10% of New York City, as well as US schools have a computer science curriculum. You will utilize the existing creativity that already exists within the spirits of children, as well as their knack for apps and video games, and channel this energy into supporting them in learning wireframing, weibsite, app & game development. If you are into Scratch, Arduino, JAVA, or HTML, this is a PLUS. Come contribute your mastery to increase the interest in STEM in our students one of our Harlem locations!
10037.title: Teach Kids How To Code: Join Our Summer STEM Program In Harlem!

10036.description: Peace of Heart Choir, directed by Robert Rene Galvan, is a non-profit volunteer chorus that promotes healing, diversity, community bonding, and mutual understanding through music. We rehearse on Thursday nights in midtown Manhattan, and we perform over 20 free concerts each year in hospitals, nursing homes, shelters, and other similar venues throughout New York City. You can learn more about us at www.peaceofheartchoir.org Auditions for our Fall 2017 season will be: Thursday, August 3rd - 7:00 PM - 9:30 PM Saturday, August 5th - 2:00 PM - 5:00 PM To schedule your audition, please contact us at peaceofheartchoir@gmail.com or 347-829-7642. We look forward to hearing from you!
10036.title: Auditions! Seeking Singers for Volunteer Choir!

10036.title: Auditions! Seeking Singers for Volunteer Choir!

10036.description: Looking for an art teacher, a recreation/gym teacher and 3 group leaders to assist with kids aged 5 - 13 for a Day Camp.
10036.title: Vacation Bible School Day Camp Volunteer

10036.description: The NY Senior Medciare Patrol works to empower and assist Medicare beneficiaries to protect themselves against healthcare fraud, learn detect errors and report Medicare abuse when suspected. We are looking for a volunteer to help us accomplish our mission by scheduling Education Sessions & Community events with Senior Centers, local senior groups, senior residences and other appropriate entities. What will your responsibilites include? Schedule SMP Education Sessions & Community events across different NY counties Confirm SMP volunteer attendance with Staff or Event Organizer Weekly communication with Volunteer Coordinator Qualifications Ability to schedule events Excellent time management & organizational skills Familiarity with community organizations (Senior Centers, Libraries, Senior Groups etc) *preferred not required Comfortable with administrative & computer work (Word, Google, Gmail) 10-15 hours/week For more information, please contact Victoria Thornton, vthornton@liveon-ny.org, 212-398-6565 ext 235
10036.title: Outreach Team Lead

10036.description: About the Foundation The Icla da Silva Foundation is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization that was founded in 1992 after the death of its namesake, Icla da Silva, who died of Leukemia at the age of 13. Prior to her death, Icla sought a potentially life-saving bone marrow transplant from a matching donor; however, a timely match was never identified. Upon her death, her family established the Foundation with the mission to save lives by recruiting bone marrow donors and by providing support services to children and adults with leukemia and other diseases treatable by marrow transplants. Now in its 25th year, the Foundation has grown to be the largest recruitment center for the Be the Match Registry. It recruits more than 38,000 new potential bone marrow donors every year, with a strong focus on minority communities. The Icla da Silva Foundation requires strong, mission-driven staff and volunteers who are talented, highly skilled and compassionate professionals. We are looking for creative thinkers who can collaborate in our life-saving work in a range of internship opportunities. Development Volunteer : The Icla da Silva Foundation is in need of a Development Volunteer to help spread the word about our organization and the importance of joining the national bone marrow registry. Responsibilities Ensure social media tools are kept up to date Develop marketing materials, presentations and proposals for corporate sponsorships Identify corporate sponsorship opportunities. Develop a Wikipedia page Update our website Identify corporate sponsorship opportunities. Make additions and changes to our database Create donation requests for raffle items Assist with event planning Help in a general administrative capacity Additional Requirements Enthusiasm for both social media and the mission and vision of the Icla da Silva Foundation. Knowledge and understanding of social media Computer/internet skills Ability to effectively communicate information and ideas in writing. Enjoy working independently as well as part of a team. Be willing to commit to 15 hours per week. Spanish and/or Portuguese speaking/writing a plus
10036.title: Events and Development Volunteer

10036.description: Senior Medicare Patrol The Senior Medicare Patrol (SMP) is a nationwide effort to educate and empower seniors to protect themselves against fraud, learn to detect errors and report healthcare abuse. With so many scams targeting seniors, volunteers have the unique opportunity to help stop healthcare fraud at the source! The NY Senior Medicare Patrol hosts Education Sessions to teach seniors a variety of tips & tricks to ensure their healthcare benefits are safe & personal information is secure from scammers. What would a Healthcare Fraud Educator do? Senior Medicare Patrol volunteers will give education sessions to various audiences of Medicare beneficiaries, caregivers & professionals in the aging industry about Medicare & Medicaid fraud/abuse. Education sessions are hosted all throughout the NY metro area, including 5 boroughs, Westchester, & Long Island No prior healthcare education? No problem! New York Senior Medicare Patrol will provide comprehensive training to interested volunteers. Contact Victoria Thornton, Volunteer Coordinator for more information! 212-398-6565 ext 235 , vthornton@liveon-ny.org
10036.title: Healthcare Fraud Educators

10036.description: Apply your marketing skills by sharing your thoughts about our work and telling us how you think we can improve! Are you a fan of jazz and blues? Did you know that hundreds of accomplished musicians will face a serious crisis in the next year? Some 700 others will struggle to fill gaps in already meager performance schedules. Jazz and blues musicians are our heroes - so let's connect them with audiences across the country for free, fairly paying gigs! Students, seniors, general audiences... we do all kinds of shows (total 900 each year), we just need to first partner with nonprofits that can provide a space and equipment, which requires some serious promotional materials and applications for funding. That's where you come in!
10036.title: Marketing Consultant to Empower Elder Jazz Musicians

10036.description: The New York Senior Medicare Patrol (SMP) is part of a nationwide campaign to educate Medicare beneficiaries about healthcare fraud. Our mission is to reduce fraud by empowering beneficiaries to prevent, detect and report Medicare errors and abuse. We want to ensure that older adults do not have to fall victim to this abuse. SMP Volunteer Complex Interactions Specialist Volunteers who handle complex issues work individually with beneficiaries to report specific instances of suspected health care fraud, error and abuse. They help beneficiaries distinguish error from potential fraud or abuse and act on the beneficiary's behalf to correct errors and refer suspected fraud and abuse to the appropriate authorities. Volunteers who handle complex issues respond to beneficiary and caregiver inquiries that involve complaints of fraud, error, and abuse by: Interviewing the beneficiary and/or caregiver in person or by telephone Researching issues using SMP manuals and other Medicare program integrity resources Providing completed complex issues form and associated documentation of suspected fraud, error, or abuse to SMP headquarters to be reported in the SMART FACTS reporting and referrals system and for reporting to the appropriate government entity for investigation Assessing the case for further investigation and/or referral Supporting and following up with beneficiaries as their reported issue moves through the investigation and resolution process Qualifications Research and case management skills Ability and willingness to learn and share information related to preventing, detecting, and reporting health care billing mistakes, fraud, and abuse Ability to follow case referral protocols Ability to work independently Computer literacy, including ability to use the Internet and on line reporting programs Time Commitment: Volunteer schedules are flexible. The Volunteer Coordinator works with each volunteer to determine the number of hours the volunteer works each month, and to schedule assignments accordingly. Because of the training SMP volunteers receive, they are asked to commit to a minimum of one year. Training/Support: All New York SMP volunteers receive training on the SMP program, Medicare Basics, and Medicare Fraud and Abuse. Volunteers will also be invited to attend update trainings made available by the New York SMP program or other program partner agencies.
10036.title: Fraud/Abuse Specialist

10036.description: Senior Medicare Patrol The Senior Medicare Patrol (SMP) is a nationwide effort to educate and empower seniors to protect themselves against fraud, learn to detect errors and report healthcare abuse. With so many scams targeting seniors, volunteers have the unique opportunity to help stop healthcare fraud at the source! The NY Senior Medicare Patrol hosts Education Sessions to teach seniors a variety of tips & tricks to ensure their healthcare benefits are safe & personal information is secure from scammers. In effort to reach out to limited/non-English speaking communities, the Senior Medicare Patrol needs bilingual speakers to assist us with translation services. Languages needed include: Spanish, Chinese (Mandarin & Cantonese), Russian & Korean What would a Senior Medicare Patrol volunteer do? Senior Medicare Patrol volunteers will translate education sessions to various audiences of Medicare beneficiaries, caregivers & professionals in the aging industry about Medicare & Medicaid fraud/abuse. Education sessions are hosted all throughout the NY metro area, including all 5 boroughs, Westchester, & Long Island No prior healthcare education? No problem! New York Senior Medicare Patrol will provide comprehensive training to interested volunteers.
10036.title: Senior Medicare Patrol Bilingual Speakers!

10036.description: Come join us as we educate children about healthy eating, food and taste. What do Volunteers do? Volunteers are an essential component of the work that we do with children, helping out in the classroom but also providing a mentoring role for children. After participating in a hands on training, volunteers are partnered with a Spoons Across America Educator and assist in all aspects of program implementation. We look for an ongoing commitment between volunteers and a particular classroom or school, yet can also accommodate one-time volunteers. Volunteer responsibilities include assisting with program set up, working directly with children, teaching cooking skills, and assisting in the kitchen where appropriate. We are looking for individuals enthusiastic about healthy eating and children’s programming to join us! When and where are your programs? We teach programs for school children across the NYC boroughs. Programs occur throughout the school year and there are opportunities for an extended commitment as well as one-time opportunities. Will I be trained? All volunteers receive training at the Spoons Across America offices (630 Ninth Ave @ 44 th St in Manhattan), and are required to attend one of the following training dates: Wednesday March 1st: 5:00-6:30 Monday, March 6th: 12:00-1:30 What programs do you have? We have a number of on-going programs for school age children in New York City. See attached for program descriptions and our website www.spoonsacrossamerica.org. I'm ready to go! How do I sign up? If you are interested in volunteering with Spoons Across America this year. Please contact Ali McDowell, Director of Programs and Partnerships, at ali@spoonsacrossamerica.org. In your email, please indicate the following: - Training session you will attend: Wedndesday, March 1st: 5:00-6:30 or Monday, November6 th: 12:00-1:30 - Programs you are interested in. * Please note: Volunteers must complete a background check prior to the program date I want to volunteer, but I am not available right now. Will there be other opportunities to get involved? Definitely! If you are unable to volunteer at this point, we will have other opportunities available this winter and spring. If possible, please attend one of the trainings in November. Programs are ongoing and once you are trained you will be able to volunteer. Additional trainings will be held later this year. I want to volunteer, but I can’t attend the training.Will there be other trainings? Depending upon need and availability, additional trainings may be scheduled this fall. Please contact Ali with your availability. * Do you work for a business or company that wants to make a volunteer commitment? We can schedule a special training sessions for groups of 10 or more people, onsite or at our offices. Contact Ali for more information.
10036.title: Volunteer as a Food Educators in NYC Elementary Classrooms- New Trainings in March
10036.org: From Farm to Table d/b/a Spoons Across America

10036.description: The New York Senior Medicare Patrol (SMP) project is part of a nationwide campaign to educate Medicare beneficiaries about the consequences and direct impact of healthcare fraud. Last year we lost an estiimated $65 billion to Medicare fraud and abuse! Our mission is to empower and educate beneficiaries to prevent,. detect and report Medicare fraud. We work to ensure that older adults do not have to fall victim to this abuse. SMP Volunteer Complex Interactions Specialist Volunteers who handle complex issues work individually with beneficiaries to report specific instances of suspected health care fraud, error and abuse. They help beneficiaries distinguish error from potential fraud or abuse and act on the beneficiary's behalf to correct errors and refer suspected fraud and abuse to the appropriate authorities. Volunteers who handle complex issues respond to beneficiary and caregiver inquiries that involve complaints of fraud, error, and abuse by: Interviewing the beneficiary and/or caregiver in person or by telephone Researching issues using SMP manuals and other Medicare program integrity resources Providing completed complex issues form and associated documentation of suspected fraud, error, or abuse to SMP headquarters to be reported in the SMART FACTS reporting and referrals system and for reporting to the appropriate government entity for investigation Assessing the case for further investigation and/or referral Supporting and following up with beneficiaries as their reported issue moves through the investigation and resolution process Qualifications Research and case management skills Ability and willingness to learn and share information related to preventing, detecting, and reporting health care billing mistakes, fraud, and abuse Ability to follow case referral protocols Ability to work independently Computer literacy, including ability to use the Internet and on line reporting programs Time Commitment: Volunteer schedules are flexible. The Volunteer Coordinator works with each volunteer to determine the number of hours the volunteer works each month, and to schedule assignments accordingly. Because of the training SMP volunteers receive, they are asked to commit to a minimum of one year. Training/Support: All New York SMP volunteers receive training on the SMP program, Medicare Basics, and Medicare Fraud and Abuse. Volunteers will also be invited to attend update trainings made available by the New York SMP program or other program partner agencies.
10036.title: SMP Fraud/Abuse Specialist

10036.description: BUILD is an innovative, college preparatory program. We use entrepreneurship to ignite the potential of youth from under-resourced communities and propel them to high school, college & career success. Volunteer as a BUILD mentor! BUILD Mentors are placed with a high school student team, coaching them through the process of launching real businesses. This makes school more relevant and fun! Mentors can come from any professional background - sharing your skill-sets with students inspires them to stay on the path to college success. Interested in getting involved but can’t mentor weekly? BUILD has one-off and group volunteer opportunities as well. Please email Miranda Bellizia for additional information. Here are some details on what a mentoring commitment looks like: Location: Manhattan, Brooklyn or the Bronx Time commitment: 1 hour, once a week (M-Th) (Group and Virtual options available) Session runs: September 2016 - June 2017 (with winter and spring breaks) 1 mentors assigned per team (1:4 mentor to student ratio) Sites are accessible through public transportation Get started! Fill out our online application here: www.build.org/volunteer Got questions? Email us aNYCVolunteers@build.org
10036.title: Empower Youth Entrepreneurs. Be a BUILD Mentor!

10036.description: Supervisor: Helpline Manager Position Summary: Information and Referral Helpline volunteers will offer information and treatment options to callers and answer basic questions regarding body image and eating disorders in a caring and compassionate manner. This position is a great learning opportunity and involves a minimum of 15 hours of training. Primary Responsibilities: 1. Information and Referral Services: Provide positive, respectful and timely responses regarding eating disorder information requests via incoming phone calls, voicemail messages, emails, forums, instant messages, and social media sites under Helpline responsibility. Ensure the distribution of Helpline information and treatment options in a timely manner that fits the needs of the individual and is presented in a professional manner. Compose general letters of response for information requests. Develop skills related to database management. Increase knowledge and understanding concerning eating disorders and how to appropriately support those affected by them. When deemed appropriate by the Helpline Supervisor, serve as a mentor in the training of newer Helpline volunteers and interns. Contribute to the association’s mission of eliminating eating disorders and body dissatisfaction. 2. Program Duties: Assist Program department staff with ongoing educational and outreach projects. Required Qualifications: High energy, positive attitude, and enthusiasm. Meticulous attention to detail and strong organizational skills. Excellent communication skills and demonstrated ability to provide quality customer service. Strong computer skills, data entry and word-processing ability. Must be dependable and self-motivated. Able to work effectively as an individual and as part of a team. Recovery is important to us here at NEDA. We require that applicants with personal experience who are interested in getting involved with the National Eating Disorders Association have two years of strong recovery due to the intense and triggering nature of this position.
10036.title: Helpline Volunteer/Intern

10036.description: Lar Lubovitch and the Board of Directors are pleased to invite you to join the newly formed Junior Board of the Lar Lubovitch Dance Company. Membership on the Junior Board offers a unique opportunity to personally participate in the organization of this prestigious New York dance company. A short list of the benefits includes the following: -Invitations to special junior board member events throughout the year. -Attendance at private rehearsals with dancers and choreographer. -Access to a backstage experience and a chance to meet the dancers. -Acknowledgement and listed by name in all printed programs. -Priority seating for friends purchasing Gala tickets. -Involvement in the planning and staging of dance events To join the Junior Board, each member undertakes the responsibility of a $250 membership per year plus the commitment of selling 5 Gala tickets to the company’s principal event of the season.
10036.title: Seeking Junior Board Members

10036.description: UX is a development institution that is forward thinking, free of cost, and open to people of all ages. It is a new crossroads for learning. The whole city is its campus. It takes place at the All Stars Project headquarters on 42nd St. and it also takes place in corporate boadrooms and back stage at Broadway theatres, in your neighborhood and at your school, even in your living room if you want it to. It has no tuition and no grades. We are looking for mature adults of all ages, open-minded thinkers, self-starters with organization and planning skills. Good oral and written communication skills. Administrative skills; including but not limited to: Microsoft Suite & Database management. Willingness to travel throughout N.Y.C.'s five boroughs. Some evening and weekend availability a plus.
10036.title: UX - Volunteer

10036.description: Work with our dynamic Sales and Marketing Director to promote a variety of All Stars productions -- from Hip-Hop Cabarets to avante garde drama to community open houses. Work includes targeting various constituencies through online media and phone outreach. Creative ideas and campaigns are welcomed. Day time hours are best.
10036.title: Volunteer Theatre Sales Support

10036.description: The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company is world-renowned. We currently have 14 dedicated members on our Senior Board, and we are now seeking to add 3 or 4 more lovers of dance to our circle of supporters. Prospective board members should have an appreciation of dance and be willing to work with other like-minded professionals, helping the company realize its mission. The commitment of time and money are both very reasonable -- while the emotional and spiritual rewards are enormous. We would be very happy to meet with you and let you see what we are all about. Please contact us at your earliest convenience.
10036.title: Seeking Senior Board Members

10036.description: Looking for caring adults to volunteer to support an innovative performance and development program that involves more than 10,000 young people in New York City each year. In the \"All Stars Talent Show,\" every young person who auditions makes it into the show. Adult and youth volunteers work together to conduct community outreach and help produce auditions, workshops and shows. Our \"Center for Youth Development\" on West 42nd Street is the producing headquarters for these off-site productions, which take place in inner-city communities throughout New York City.
10036.title: Inner-City Youth Talent Show Support Staff

10036.description: Castillo Theatre Production Volunteer - A showplace for the plays of Fred Newman and Heiner Muller, a multicultural home for Black theatre, and a hotbed of theatrical improvisation, Castillo includes people of all ages and backgrounds in its creative life. Embarking on its 32nd season, The award winning Castillo Theater brings socially relevant theatre, dealing with contemporary and historical social issues to the heart of New York's commercial theatre district. Volunteers are needed to support all aspects of the theatre. marketing and sales,set design, costumes, wardrobe, lighting, sound, stage management, box office, house staff,theatre administration, audience development, and much more! Most positions will train. Schedules are varied and flexible; however, for some technical positions in the theatre a stable, reliable schedule is essential. Some evening and weekend availability needed.
10036.title: Castillo Theater Production Volunteer

10031.description: Google CS First Guru The Boys and Girls Club of Harlem is committed to providing access and opportunity fo r students throughout the area to reach their full potential. The Boys and Girls Club reaches students at 5 sites across Harlem. O ur mission for the CS program is to introduce kids to STEM programs at a young age . This is designed to peak an interest so students will one day enter the career field of STEM. Volunteers are crucial to the advancement of these goals. We appreciate every volunteer who comes through our door s and provide you the best skills to succeed with the organization. Should the full 2 hours work for you our sessions are 1 hour blocks. We would love to have you for just 1 hour in that window. CS first volunteer BGC Harlem is seeking a dedicated individual to teach a computer science program to students during the summer We will provide all training necessary to make sure you are confident with your skills before placing you in the classroom We understand you may have a very busy schedule, however, we would ask for 2 hours a day 1-2 days per week. College and high school students looking for volunteer hours are strongly encouraged to apply.
10031.title: Google CS First Guru

10031.description: We make sure all our volunteers are recognize for their hard work.The volunteers will be welcome into a basketball family Program
10031.title: Playing on the Edge Basketball Program Inc.
10031.org: Playing On The Edge Basketball Program Inc

10031.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for volunteer tutors to provide academic support to Urban Scholars at the City College of New York during the summer. We are currently seeking tutors for math, science, reading, and social science to support high school students as they prepare for their SATs. You would work with a group of students for 2 hours per week between 2:30 - 6:00 PM, Mondays-Thursdays. (You can do this on one day.) This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience, and who would like to leverage their knowledge in the subject area to support others with their learning growth and development. As a tutor, you will collaborate with a local coordinator to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by experienced academic support professionals. To apply, you must: 1. Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor. 2. Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have received a degree recently. 3. Be willing to complete 11.5 hours of College Reading and Learning Aligned (CRLA) training at City College of New York. All tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Summer semester. We can accommodate your schedule for the live trainings. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having tutors in these sessions early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about Urban Scholars here: https://www.ccny.cuny.edu/gca/urban-scholars
10031.title: Summer 2017 Math/Science/Reading/Writing Tutors Needed for Urban Scholars

10031.description: City Tutors (CT), the tutoring arm of the Colin Powell School, is currently looking for two tutors to provide academic support for students in Intermediate Micro and Macroeconomics courses. Tutors for the Intermediate Economics courses will serve in the role of study group leaders. In this role, you would take the lead to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by CT coordinators. All majors are welcome to apply. This is a great opportunity especially for Economics/Business Management/Finance majors or minors. You should consider applying if you are interested in building professional contacts with faculty and staff at the Colin Powell School who can later speak to your professional capability at the cross section of your academic interests, would like to help your peers and make an impact on students' classroom learning experience, and if you are interested in exploring your academic interest area at the cross section of education. If you are applying for the study group leader position supporting the Intermediate Economics courses, you need to have taken the same intermediate economics course you wish to tutor, received A- or A in that economics course, have an overall GPA at 3.2 or higher All City Tutors are expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Fall semester. If you are unable to attend the regular training sessions, you will need to attend makeup sessions. The dates for these sessions will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinator’s. Learn more about the City Tutors here: thecitytutors.com The City Tutors (CT) was founded at The City College of New York with the premise that a volunteer tutoring program working collaboratively with educational partners can help improve retention and graduation rates.
10031.title: Fall 2017 Seeking Volunteer Tutors to Support Courses in Intermediate Micro and/or Macro Economics

10031.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for a tutor to run study groups that provide academic support for CCNY Biology 102 class students for the Fall 2017 Semester. Biology 102 is an introductory course for science students. Classes in the Spring met twice a week on Mondays and Wednesdays from 3:30pm to 4:45pm, though this schedule may change for the Fall 2017 semester. This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience, and for those who are interested in tutoring in their subject area of interest. In this role, you will be in communication with an instructor to improve students’ performance. Throughout this process, you will be supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. A tutor supporting this Biology 102 class is expected to commit a minimum of three hours and thirty minutes every week. You will need to attend both the Monday and Wednesday classes (assuming schedule remains unchanged), as well as provide a minimum of one hour study group support. Study group times will be determined from a survey done in class asking when students will be available for sessions. Times that fit with the majority of students and the tutor will be selected for study groups. You would identify and support students who are struggling, and provide feedback to the instructor regarding students' concerns and difficulties that can lead to changes in future lessons. You will also meet with the CCNY Biology Department staff. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All tutors are expected to complete 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Fall semester. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having a tutor support class early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about CCNY Biology Department here: https://www.ccny.cuny.edu/biology To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree program receiving higher than a 3.0 Make monthly meetings, keep a log sheet of any tutoring appointments done outside of class, and regularly communicate with the tutor training coordinator.
10031.title: Fall 2017 Biology Tutor needed for Bio 102 course held through the CCNY Biology Department

10031.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for tutors to provide in-class academic support in math for the Continuing Professional Studies at CCNY for the Fall 2017 semester. Classes in the mornings can run Mondays and Wednesdays, or Tuesdays and Thursdays. The class runs from 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM. This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience and who are interested in tutoring. In this role, you would collaborate with an instructor to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. The tutor for Continuing Professional Studies is expected to commit a minimum of two hours every week to support one of the above-mentioned days. Tutors can attend for two hours on one day, or for one hour on both days that the class meets. You would identify and support students who are struggling, participate during the lecture to augment the class topic discussions, and provide feedback to students so that they may improve their fundamental understanding of the material. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Fall semester. Training days will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinators. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having a tutor in the class early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about Continuing Professional Studies here: https://www.ccny.cuny.edu/cps To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree program Submit monthly reports, keep a log sheet of any tutoring appointments done outside of class, and regularly communicate with the tutor training coordinator.

10031.description: The City Tutors (CT) is looking for tutors to provide in-class academic support in reading and writing for the Continuing Professional Studies at CCNY for the Fall 2017 semester. Classes in the evenings can run Mondays and Wednesdays, or Tuesdays and Thursdays. The class runs from 6:00 AM - 9:00 PM. This is a great opportunity for students who are majoring (or have already earned a degree) in the course area to enhance their knowledge and experience and who are interested in tutoring. In this role, you would collaborate with an instructor to improve students’ performance while being supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. The tutor for Continuing Professional Studies is expected to commit a minimum of two hours every week to support one of the above-mentioned days. Tutors can attend for two hours on one day, or for one hour on both days that the class meets. You would identify and support students who are struggling, participate during the lecture to augment the class topic discussions, and provide feedback to students so that they may improve their fundamental understanding of the material. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. You will be supported throughout this process by the City Tutors staff. All tutors are also expected to complete a four session comprehensive, professional training regimen. 6 hours of live training, plus another hour and a half for orientation. This is a commitment of 7.5 hours of in person training, and 4 hours of supplemental training for a total of 11.5 hours of training over the course of the Fall semester. Training days will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinators. CT's tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having a tutor in the class early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support. Learn more about Continuing Professional Studies here: https://www.ccny.cuny.edu/cps To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree program Submit monthly reports, keep a log sheet of any tutoring appointments done outside of class, and regularly communicate with the tutor training coordinator.
10031.title: Reading/Writing Tutor needed for Evening CCNY Continuing Professional Studies Fall 2017

10031.description: Description: The City Tutors-The City College of New York, are looking for a self-motivated, detailed oriented and creative graphic designer to assist with visuals for The City Tutors. Responsibilities Assist and create visuals for manuals, websites, and social media accounts Pitch ideas for visuals Required Skills Proficiency in Photoshop, Adobe InDesign, and Illustrator Knowledge of FinalCut Pro Strong typographic knowledge and a good sense of layout design Recommended Strong typographic knowledge and a good sense of layout design Front-end web design experience is also a plus The City Tutors are a volunteer organization that has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Our opportunities allow our volunteers to develop professional development skills for the purpose of gaining future employment.
10031.title: Graphic Designer Intern

10031.description: The City Tutors (CT) provides academic support for College Now students in Physics. We are currently looking for tutor to be embedded in the classroom for the Fall semester of 2017. The Saturday classs meets from 9:00 AM to 1:00 PM on Saturdays. As an embedded tutor, you will collaborate with an instructor to improve students’ performance, while being supported and guided by an experienced academic support professional. All embedded tutors for the College Now classes are expected to commit to four hours per class session. You will sit in on the class, and sometimes provide tutoring support after class (or on a different day if that's more agreeable) depending on students’ availability and interest. You would identify and support students who are struggling, participate during the lecture to augment the class topic discussions, and provide feedback to the instructor regarding students' concerns and difficulties that can lead to changes in future lessons. You might also design assignments, identify/track students who are struggling and create differentiated instruction as the need arises. CT's embedded tutoring program has been successful in helping students gain access to support that they otherwise would not have received, given their limited time spent on campus. Having a tutor in the class early in the semester will allow us to employ strategies to reduce withdrawals and student failure rates. Your work with us would help the students’ overall subject area performance, and help us improve this educational support model, reaching more students and departments with comprehensive academic support.. To apply, you must: Have received an A- or A in the introduction to the subject course you are applying to tutor Have a GPA at or above 3.2, or have completed a degree in physics or other related sciences Submit biweekly reports, and meet through Google Hangout/in person with the director on a biweekly basis. Be willing to complete 11.5 hours of College Reading and Learning Aligned (CRLA) training. Training days will be determined based on your schedule and that of the Tutor Training Coordinators.
10031.title: Saturday Physics Classroom Tutor for College Now for Fall 2017
